THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        George H.
          Seago, III, and Real Estate Information Service, Inc., Appellants,
        v.
        Horry County, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
  Â J. Stanton Cross, Jr., Circuit Court
Judge

Opinion No.Â  26505
Heard March 5, 2008 - Filed June 16, 2008 

AFFIRMED IN PART, 
  REVERSED IN PART,
AND REMANDED


  
    
      
        Jay
          Bender and Holly Palmer Beeson, both of Baker, Ravenel and Bender, of Columbia, for Appellants.
        Emma
          Ruth Brittain and Matthew R. Magee, both of Thompson and Henry, of Myrtle Beach, for Respondent.
      
    
  


JUSTICE
  BEATTY:Â  This case
  concerns whether further dissemination of public documents obtained pursuant to
  a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request may be restricted where the
  government entity claims the information is copyright-protected under the
  federal copyright law.Â  We affirm the circuit courtâ€™s finding that, while
  public information must be granted pursuant to FOIA, a public entity may
  restrict further commercial distribution of the information pursuant to a
  copyright.Â  However, we reverse and remand for further proceedings on the
  question regarding the fees charged.Â  
FACTUAL BACKGROUND
George
  Seago, III, and his company, Real Estate Information Service, Inc.,
  (collectively, Appellants), collect electronic mapping data from various
  government entities across the state for their website and allow customers,
  including real estate developers, realtors, mortgage companies, appraisers,
  attorneys, and others, access to the information from their website for a fee.Â 
  The fees range from $350 to $3,000 per year, and up to $40,000 per year for one
  particular subscriber.Â  Subscribers are issued a password to access the website
  and are prohibited from sharing their passwords with others.Â  
Horry Countyâ€™s geographic information systems (GIS) department developed a digital database
  to combine several layers of information onto one digital photographic map of
  the county.Â  The GIS department took over 4,000 orthophoto, or aerial images,
  of the county and compressed them into a seamless collage in the â€œMr. Sidâ€
  computer format.Â  The GIS department processed flat file data,[1] including data regarding planimetric
  layers,[2] parcels, and topography, through a spatial database engine (SDE) to convert the
  flat file data into lines, points, or images on the photographic map.Â  As
  information regarding the land in the County is constantly changing, the
  information in the flat files has to be constantly updated.Â  Thus, there is not
  one document; a map of a specific region or local has to be â€œcreatedâ€ by
  running the requested flat file information through the database to produce the
  requested map.Â  According to Timothy Oliver, Assistant Director of the GIS department,
  this process is unique to Horry County and requires creativity and judgment on
  the part of the GIS department to know how to combine the different flat files
  to create an integrated, aerial-photographed map that precisely identifies the
  location of parcels, bodies of water, streets, buildings, hydrology, and
  topography.Â  
 Horry County developed its digital database system at a cost of $7.5 million dollars.Â 
  Because of the constantly changing information regarding property in the
  County, it costs nearly $1 million each year to update the information in the
  flat files.Â  To protect its investment and the integrity of the data from
  manipulation or alteration by subsequent users, Horry County applied for
  copyrights for its planimetric layers data and orthophoto Mr. Sid data.[3]Â  
On
  December 5, 2001, Seago made a FOIA request for a copy of the â€œOrthophoto
  Coverage in Mr. Sid format (Countywide)â€ so he could place the digital
  photographic map on his website for use by his customers.Â  In January 2002,
  Lisa Bourcier, Director of Public Information for Horry County, informed Seago
  that he could obtain a copy of the information for a fee of $100, but he would
  have to sign a licensing agreement acknowledging Horry Countyâ€™s copyright on
  the information and restricting any further commercial use without prior
  written consent.Â  Seago did not object to the fee, but he refused to sign the
  licensing agreement.Â  Seago did not obtain the requested information.Â  
On
  August 29, 2002, Seago again made a FOIA request for full-county coverage GIS
  data for planimetric layers, topographic layers, and parcel layers in ArcInfo
  Shapefile or ArcInfo export formats.Â  Seago included a check for $125, which he
  had previously been informed was the charge for the data, and his request
  specifically noted that he would only sign a licensing agreement if Horry County could show authority to copyright public information.Â  On September 20, 2002,
  Bourcier returned Seagoâ€™s check and informed him that Horry County could not process his request at that time because the requested information contained
  â€œcopyrightable elements,â€ and Horry County had retained copyright attorneys to
  research and copyright what was appropriate.Â  On October 1, 2002, the Horry
  County Council held their first reading of a proposed ordinance to require a
  special fee schedule and a licensing agreement for the distribution of GIS
  information.Â  Seago continued to receive letters from Bourcier, alternately
  informing him:Â  (1) that his request could not be processed at that time; (2)
  that his request was for copyrightable information; (3) that the requested
  information was not subject to FOIA because the county possessed no document
  that â€œprovides the complex information you seekâ€ and it would have to be
  created; and (4) that Horry County was attempting to pass the fee and licensing
  ordinance.Â  After Seago initiated the underlying lawsuit for a FOIA violation,
  Bourcier wrote him a letter pointing out Seagoâ€™s misunderstanding that he was
  being denied access and stating Seagoâ€™s FOIA requests would have been granted
  if only he had signed the licensing agreement.Â  
Appellantsâ€™
  lawsuit sought a declaratory judgment that:Â  Horry Countyâ€™s charges for copies
  exceeded the actual cost of making copies; the restrictions on the use of the
  documents by the County was an ultra vires act; and there is no FOIA
  exception for records containing copyrightable elements.Â  Horry County counterclaimed for copyright infringement and later removed the matter to federal
  court.Â  After the parties argued the case in front of the federal magistrate,
  the district court adopted the magistrateâ€™s recommendation that the case was
  strictly an application of state FOIA law and dismissed the matter.Â  
In
  state court, the parties agreed to refer the matter to the master-in-equity,
  and Horry County later dismissed its counterclaims.Â  In an amended order, the
  master determined:Â  (1) the requested information constituted a public record
  subject to disclosure under FOIA because the definition of â€œpublic recordâ€ is
  broad enough to include the documentary materials that the flat file records
  could be exported into; (2) Horry County could copyright its materials, and the
  copyright protections could be read harmoniously with FOIA, because the right
  to access public documents is separate and distinct from any right to
  subsequent distribution; (3) FOIA is satisfied once access is granted to the
  information; and (4) Horry County could impose a licensing fee in excess of the
  cost of reproducing the data â€œwhere, as under the circumstances of this case,
  the data is being released for purposes that extend beyond initial access to a
  public record as allowed by FOIA,â€ and in light of Seagoâ€™s testimony that he
  had no objection to the fees being charged to him.Â Â Â  This appeal follows.
SCOPE OF REVIEW
â€œA
  declaratory judgment action under the FOIA to determine whether certain
  information should be disclosed is an action at law.â€Â  Campbell v.
    Marion County Hosp. Dist., 354 S.C. 274, 280, 580 S.E.2d 163, 165 (Ct. App.
  2003) (citing S.C. Tax Commâ€™n v. Gaston Copper Recycling Corp., 316 S.C.
  163, 447 S.E.2d 843 (1994)).Â  In an action at law tried without a jury, this
  Court reviews the lower court only to correct errors of law.Â  Crary v.
    Djebelli, 329 S.C. 385, 388, 496 S.E.2d 21, 23 (1998).Â  The trial courtâ€™s
  factual findings will not be disturbed on appeal unless there is no evidence in
  the record that would reasonably support the findings.Â  Harkins v. Greenville County, 340 S.C. 606, 621, 533 S.E.2d 886, 893 (2000).

DISCUSSION[4]
I.Â  Restrictions on subsequent use under FOIA
Appellants argue the master erred in finding Horry County could restrict subsequent distribution of public records because:Â  (1) FOIA
  does not include an exception for disclosure for records containing â€œcopyrightable
  elements;â€ and (2) FOIA does not authorize restrictions on subsequent use.Â  
The purpose of FOIA is to protect citizens from secret
  government activity.Â  Campbell, 354 S.C. at 280, 580 S.E.2d at 166.Â 
  FOIA allows the public to â€œlearn and report fully the activities of their
  public officials at a minimum cost or delayâ€ by providing the public access to
  public documents[5] or meetings.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 30-4-15 (2007).Â  Pursuant to FOIA, any person
  has the right to copy public records, unless an exception applies, at a fee
  â€œnot to exceed the actual cost of searching for or making copies of records.â€Â 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 30-4-30(a), (b) (2007).Â  Any government agency attempting to
  avail itself of an exemption bears the burden of proving the exemption applies.Â  Evening Post Publâ€™g Co. v. City of North Charleston, 363 S.C. 452, 457,
  611 S.E.2d 496, 499 (2005).Â  The exemptions to FOIA should be narrowly
  construed to ensure public access to documents.Â  Id.Â  
FOIA grants the public an immutable right to access public
  records.Â  However, this right of access is viewed differently where commercial
  use of public information is concerned.Â  FOIA specifically limits the
  subsequent commercial use of information obtained pursuant to the Act in some
  situations:Â  (1) public records containing the telephone number, address, and
  name of handicapped persons may not be disclosed where the information is to be
  used for person-to-person commercial solicitation of such handicapped person;
  and (2) information contained in a police incident report, or in an employee
  salary schedule, or the home addresses and phone numbers of employees and
  officers of public bodies may not be used for commercial solicitation.Â  S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§ 30-4-40(a)(2) (2007) (providing the government may exempt from
  disclosure contact information for handicapped persons if it is to be used for
  commercial solicitation); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 30-4-50(B) (2007) (prohibiting the
  use of information in a police report, employee salary schedule, or the home
  addresses of public body employees and officers for commercial solicitation).Â  
While it is true that copyright-protected data is not listed as an
  exemption to FOIA disclosure, Horry County does not deny this fact and there is
  evidence in the record to support the masterâ€™s finding that Horry County was not attempting to restrict initial access to the material by Appellants.Â 
  Thus, the question before the Court is whether Horry County may restrict the subsequent
    commercial distribution of public information pursuant to the copyright
  law.Â  
In deciding this question, the master relied upon the federal case
  of County of Suffolk, New York v. First American Real Estate
    Solutions, 261 F.3d 179 (2d Cir. 2001).Â  In Suffolk, Suffolk County sued First American for copyright infringement for copying and selling Suffolk Countyâ€™s copyrighted tax maps.Â  The Suffolk court found that states and
  political subdivisions may obtain copyrights, and maps could be
  copyright-protected to the extent it could be shown that it contained original
  material, research, and creative compilation.Â  Suffolk, 261 F.3d at
  187-88.Â  The court next considered whether the New York Freedom of Information
  Law (FOIL) abrogated Suffolk Countyâ€™s copyright.Â  Noting that when FOIL was
  enacted it was recognized that states could possess copyrights, the court found
  it significant that FOIL was silent as to the effect of requiring disclosure on
  preexisting copyrights the agency possessed and what may occur after the agency
  discloses the records.Â  Id. at 189.Â  The court found the extent of the
  state agencyâ€™s FOIL obligation is to make its records available for public
  inspection and copying, stating that it â€œis one thing to read this provision to
  permit a member of the public to copy a public record, but it is quite another
  to read into it the right of a private entity to distribute commercially what
  it would otherwise, under copyright law, be unable to distribute.â€Â  Id.[6] Â 
Because FOIA does not prohibit the copyrighting of some
  specialized public information, we agree with the Suffolk courtâ€™s
  reasoning that the county may obtain copyrights, and maps can be
  copyright-protected to the extent it can be shown that it contains original
  material, research, and creative compilation.Â  Suffolk, 261 F.3d at
  187-88.Â  The originality and creativity necessary to create and maintain the
  system is present in this case.Â  Further, the purpose of FOIA is satisfied once
  the public information is provided.Â  It does not violate FOIA for a public
  entity to copyright specially-created digital data and to restrict subsequent commercial use as long as the information is provided initially to the requesting person
  or entity.Â  If an entity is allowed to copyright the specially-created data, it
  is logical that the governmental entity should be allowed to enact ordinances
  to restrict further commercial dissemination of the information in order to
  protect the copyright.Â  See 17 U.S.C.A. Â§ 106 (2005) (providing that
  copyright holders have the exclusive right to allow certain uses, and thus
  impose subsequent use restrictions).Â Â  
However, Appellants point to the Court of Appealsâ€™ decision in Campbell
  v. Marion County Hospital District, 354 S.C. 274, 580 S.E.2d 163 (Ct. App. 2003), to support their argument that FOIA prohibits any subsequent use
  restriction on public information.Â  In Campbell, the circuit court ruled
  that Dr. Campbell could get access to the county hospitalâ€™s records of physician
  recruitment, physiciansâ€™ salaries, and purchase prices of practices pursuant to
  FOIA, but the circuit court ruled such information constituted â€œtrade secretsâ€
  such that the court restricted Dr. Campbell from subsequently disclosing the
  information to third parties.Â  Campbell, 354 S.C. at 278-79, 580 S.E.2d
  165.Â  The Court of Appeals reversed the circuit courtâ€™s protective order,
  finding the information did not constitute â€œtrade secretsâ€ and that information
  obtained pursuant to FOIA could not be protected by a restraining order.Â  Id. at 287, 580 S.E.2d at 169.Â  While the Campbell opinion correctly noted
  that FOIA does not provide for the prohibition on further dissemination of
  information obtained, the case did not deal with the interplay of federal
  copyright restrictions and licensing on subsequent commercial dissemination of
  the information.Â  Thus, Campbell is not applicable to the underlying
  case.Â  Â Â 
Accordingly, we agree with the master that FOIA and copyright law
  can be â€œread harmoniouslyâ€ and that the Horry County ordinance allowing the
  licensing restrictions on further commercial dissemination of the GIS data does
  not violate FOIA.Â  The ability to copyright specially-created data, as long as
  the public is given access to the public data, does not frustrate the purpose
  of FOIA.
II. Jurisdiction
  to determine copyright claim
Appellants
  argue the master was without jurisdiction to make any findings of fact
  regarding copyrights because it is within the exclusive jurisdiction of federal
  courts.Â  
Federal
  district courts have original jurisdiction to hear any civil actions â€œarising
  underâ€ any Act of Congress relating to copyrights.Â  28 U.S.C.A. Â§ 1338(a)
  (1999).Â  The mere fact that a case concerns a copyright does not necessarily
  mean the case comes within the exclusive jurisdiction of the federal courts.Â  Enhanced
    Computer Solutions, Inc. v. Rose, 927 F.Supp. 738, 739 (S.D.N.Y. 1996).Â  An
  action arises under the federal copyright law where the complaint seeks a
  remedy specifically granted by the Copyright Act or requires construction of
  the Act.Â  Merchant v. Levy, 92 F.3d 51, 55 (2d Cir. 1996).Â  â€œMany
  disputes over copyright ownership will arise under state law and involve no
  federal questions.â€Â  Arthur Young & Co. v. City of Richmond, 895
  F.2d 967, 969 (4th Cir. 1990).
In the
  underlying case, Horry County counterclaimed for copyright infringement, sought
  damages, and removed the case to federal court.Â  At the argument before the
  district court magistrate, Appellants asserted they were not challenging Horry Countyâ€™s ability to own a copyright, but they were instead challenging the ability to
  assert copyright protection to circumvent FOIA.Â  Appellants argued that the
  case was not a matter of whether a copyright existed, but it was rather a
  matter of exclusive state law concerning whether Horry County could withhold
  public information.Â  Appellants later argued that whether Horry County has the authority to obtain a copyright is a question of state law and the extent of
  such copyright is a federal question.Â  The district court adopted the
  magistrateâ€™s recommendation that the case be remanded to state court because
  the case did not involve the â€œvalidity, scope, or infringement of a copyright
  claimâ€ and the case related specifically to state law requests pursuant to
  FOIA.Â Â Â Â  
Despite
  moving to remand the matter to state court, arguing before the magistrate that
  they were not challenging the ability of Horry County to obtain a copyright,
  and failing to appeal the district courtâ€™s finding that the case did not
  involve the validity of a copyright, Appellants now argue the master was
  without jurisdiction to find Horry County had a copyright and was entitled to
  protect its interests.Â  In light of Appellantsâ€™ previous concession, the fact
  that the case concerned matters of interpreting state FOIA law, and the fact
  that the case did not concern a challenge under the Copyright Act, we find the
  master had jurisdiction to make a finding that a copyright existed.Â  The
  Appellantâ€™s argument is wholly without merit.
III. Licensing
  fee
Appellants
  argue the master erred in finding the licensing fees charged by Horry County
  did not violate FOIA because:Â  (1) the fees exceed the actual costs for making
  copies; and (2) the fees are not charged uniformly for the same records.Â  
FOIA
  provides that a â€œpublic body may establish and collect fees not to exceed the
  actual cost of searching for or making copies of records,â€ and the fees must be
  uniform for copies of the same record or document.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 30-4-30(b)
  (2007).Â  â€œThe records must be furnished at the lowest possible cost to the
  person requesting the records.â€Â  Id.Â  However, the public body may
  decide not to charge a fee where it determines the waiver of the fee is in the
  public interest because â€œfurnishing the information can be considered as
  primarily benefitting the general public.â€Â  Id.Â  
The Horry County ordinance provides different licensing fees for copying GIS data, depending on
  the intended use.Â  Timothy Oliver, Assistant Director of Horry Countyâ€™s GIS department, testified before the master that Horry County provides GIS data to
  certain public entities at no cost, including the U.S. Fish and Wildlife
  Service, the City of North Myrtle Beach, and Ocean and Coastal Resource
  Management.Â  Oliver also testified that while the money charged for the record
  may exceed the actual cost of copying it, the cost is associated with the copyright
  license use and not the FOIA request.Â  Horry County places the license fees
  collected in one account for use in maintaining the system and had collected
  nearly $30,000 from 2003 until the September 2005 hearing.Â  Seago testified at
  the hearing that he had no objection to the fees charged, tendering checks in
  the amounts of $100 and $125, and his only complaint was the attempt to
  restrict subsequent commercial use of the information.Â Â  
Noting
  that Seago did not object to the fees being charged to him, the master found
  the County could impose a licensing fee in excess of actual cost of
  reproduction â€œwhere, as under the circumstances of this case, the data is being
  released for purposes that extend beyond initial access to a public record as
  allowed by FOIA.â€Â Â Â  
First, we
  find no FOIA violation where Horry County waives fees to public entities.Â  The
  FOIA statute specifically provides that copying fees can be waived where it is
  in the interest of the public.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 30-4-30(b) (2007).Â  Providing
  these documents for free to public entities that intend to use them for public
  benefit and not for commercial gain would certainly fit under this category.Â  
The question of whether Horry County can charge â€œlicensing feesâ€
  that would exceed the actual copying costs pursuant to a FOIA request is a more
  difficult question.Â  FOIA requires the actual copying fees be charged at the
  lowest possible cost to the requesting party.Â  Horry County avers that the
  county did not charge Appellants for documents requested pursuant to the FOIA,
  the charge was for the license to commercially distribute the copyrighted data.
  Appellants argue classifying the fee schedule as a â€œlicensing feeâ€ instead of a
  copying fee is merely a matter of semantics where the fee is for the production
  of a public document.Â  Appellants are technically correct that Horry County never provided the documents/data to Appellants in the first place, as is
  required under FOIA.Â  However, after they tendered the requested fee, Horry County informed Appellants that signing the licensing agreement was a prerequisite to
  the production of the data.Â  Thus, it is clear that the fee was not for the production
  of the document; it was for the subsequent commercial distribution of the
  document.Â  
FOIA limitations on the fee structure for providing copies of
  public records are applicable only to those copies that are provided in keeping
  with the spirit of FOIA.Â  FOIA fee provisions do not contemplate subsequent
  commercial distribution of copyright-protected documents for profit.
FOIA is unambiguous in setting forth the method of determining
  fees for providing copies contemplated by the Act.Â  This method does not change
  depending on the status of the requester.Â  However, FOIA does not control fees
  for subsequent commercial distribution for profit of copyrighted public
  records.
The undisputed evidence in the record is that the licensing fees
  charged for the GIS data exceeded actual copying costs.Â  However, no evidence
  was introduced as to what those actual copying costs would be in non-licensing situations.Â 
  The fees in this case, while in excess of actual copying costs, do not appear
  to be exorbitant.Â  Without knowing the actual costs of producing a copy of the
  GIS data, we cannot determine whether the fees charged frustrate the intent of
  FOIA in light of the intended commercial use and Horry Countyâ€™s desire to
  protect its copyright.Â  Accordingly, we find it is more appropriate to remand
  the fee question for the determination of what the actual copying costs would be
  and whether the fees charged were so out of line with the actual copying costs such
  that the fees would frustrate the intent of FOIA. 
CONCLUSION
Horry County is not prohibited from obtaining copyrights on the Countyâ€™s GIS data which was
  specially-created; Horry County could use its copyright to protect the GIS data
  from subsequent commercial use without violating FOIA.Â  Although Horry County could use its copyright to protect the GIS data from subsequent commercial
  distribution for profit, it may not refuse to honor the initial FOIA request.Â  Further,
  the master had jurisdiction to determine the effect of Horry Countyâ€™s copyright on the FOIA action.Â  The question of whether the fees charged violate FOIA
  cannot be determined by the record before us because there is no evidence
  regarding what the actual copying costs would be.Â  Without this information, we
  cannot determine whether the fees frustrate the purpose of FOIA.Â  We remand the
  matter to the lower court for a determination of the amount of the fees,
  whether the fees charged were so out of line with the actual cost as to
  frustrate FOIA, and whether charging different fees based on the identity of
  the requester amounted to a violation.Â  Â 
MOORE,
  Acting Chief Justice, WALLER, J., and Acting Justices E. C. Burnett, III and
  James R. Barber, concur.

[1]Â 
  â€œFlat fileâ€ data is a computer file spreadsheet that only contains numbers and
information.Â  It is not in the format of a map.Â  
[2]Â 
  â€œPlanimetricâ€ data includes things such as building footprints, rivers, bodies
of water, hydrology, and streets.Â Â Â  
[3]Â  The record indicates the copyrighted works were
  â€œpublishedâ€ in January 1999 but not registered until February 2003.Â  It appears
  from the record that the copyrights retroactively applied to the works
  originally produced in January 1999.Â  In any event, Appellants do not challenge
  Horry Countyâ€™s ability to obtain a copyright; they challenge the effect of
  the copyright on their FOIA claim and the lower courtâ€™s ability to interpret
the copyright law.Â Â Â Â Â  Â 
[4]Â 
  Appellants raise five issues, including a catch-all issue complaining about all
  the masterâ€™s factual findings.Â  For the sake of clarity, we have combined them
into three.Â  
[5]Â  Horry County does not challenge the masterâ€™s finding that the GIS
  data, no matter what format it was in, constituted a â€œpublic recordâ€ subject to
FOIA.
[6]Â 
  We note there is a similar case from Florida in which the Florida state court
  distinguished Suffolk and held exactly the opposite.Â  Microdecisions,
    Inc., v. Skinner, 889 So. 2d 871 (Fla. Dis. Ct. App. 2004).Â  In Microdecisions,
  a real estate company seeking county GIS tax maps for commercial use brought
  suit against the county appraiser who refused to provide the public maps
  without the signing of a licensing agreement.Â  The court noted, â€œFloridaâ€™s Constitution and its statutes do not permit public records to be copyrighted
  unless the legislature specifically states they can be.â€Â  Microdecisions,
    Inc., 889 So. 2d at 876.Â  Unlike the case in Microdecisions, while
  our Legislature and state constitution do not specifically allow counties to
copyright, they do not specifically prohibit it, either.

The Supreme Court of South Carolina
In the Matter of Anderson County  Magistrate Michael F. Smith, Respondent.

ORDER

The Office of Disciplinary Counsel has filed a petition asking the Court to place respondent on interim suspension pursuant to Rule 17(a) and Rule 17(b) of the Rules for Judicial Disciplinary Enforcement, Rule 502, SCACR.
 IT IS ORDERED that the petition is granted and respondent is placed on interim suspension.  Anderson County is under no obligation to pay respondent his salary during the suspension.  See In the Matter of Ferguson, 304 S.C. 216, 403 S.E.2d 628 (1991).  Respondent is directed to immediately deliver all books, records, funds, property, and documents relating to his judicial office to the Chief Magistrate of Anderson County.  He is enjoined from access to any monies, bank accounts, and records related to his judicial office.
 IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that respondent is prohibited from entering the premises of the magistrate court unless escorted by a law enforcement officer after authorization from the Chief Magistrate of Anderson County.  Finally, respondent is prohibited from having access to, destroying, or canceling any public records and he is prohibited from access to any judicial databases or case management systems. 
 This Order, when served on any bank or other financial institution maintaining any judicial accounts of respondent, shall serve as notice to the institution that respondent is enjoined from making withdrawals from the accounts. 
 II IS SO ORDERED.


  
     
    s/Jean Hoefer Toal C.J.
      FOR THE COURT
  

Columbia, South Carolina
June 11, 2008

The Supreme Court of South Carolina
In the Matter of Howard Hammer, Respondent.

ORDER

The Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) petitions the Court to place respondent on interim suspension pursuant to Rule 17, RLDE, of Rule 413, SCACR.  In addition, ODC requests the Court appoint an attorney to protect respondent’s clients’ interests pursuant to Rule 31, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR. 
 IT IS ORDERED that respondent’s license to practice law in this state is suspended until further order of the Court.
 IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that H. Patterson McWhirter, Esquire, is hereby appointed to assume responsibility for respondent’s client files, trust account(s), escrow account(s), operating account(s), and any other law office account(s) respondent may maintain.  Mr. McWhirter shall take action as required by Rule 31, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR, to protect the interests of respondent’s clients.  Mr. McWhirter may make disbursements from respondent’s trust account(s), escrow account(s), operating account(s), and any other law office account(s) respondent may maintain that are necessary to effectuate this appointment.
 This Order, when served on any bank or other financial institution maintaining trust, escrow and/or operating accounts of respondent, shall serve as an injunction to prevent respondent from making withdrawals from the account(s) and shall further serve as notice to the bank or other financial institution that H. Patterson McWhirter, Esquire, has been duly appointed by this Court.
 Finally, this Order, when served on any office of the United States Postal Service, shall serve as notice that H. Patterson McWhirter, Esquire, has been duly appointed by this Court and has the authority to receive respondent’s mail and the authority to direct that respondent’s mail be delivered to Mr. McWhirter’s office.
 This appointment shall be for a period of no longer than nine months unless request is made to this Court for an extension. 
 IT IS SO ORDERED. 


  
     
    s/Jean Hoefer Toal C.J.
      FOR THE COURT
  

Columbia, South Carolina
June 12, 2008

title: In the Matter of William Gary White, III

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        In the Matter
          of William Gary White, III, Respondent.
      
    
  


Opinion No. 26482
  Heard April 1, 2008 - Refiled June 23,
2008

DEFINITE SUSPENSION 


  
    
      
        Lesley M. Coggiola, Disciplinary Counsel, C. Tex Davis, Jr., Senior
          Assistant Disciplinary Counsel, of Columbia; for Office of Disciplinary Counsel.
        Irby E. Walker, Jr., of Conway; for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â Â  This is an attorney disciplinary matter
  involving a Complaint against William Gary White, III (Respondent) for his
  representation of a client in a personal injury case.Â  After a full
  investigation by the Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC), the Commission on
  Lawyer Conduct filed formal charges against Respondent.Â  After a hearing before
  the Commission on Lawyer Conduct Panel (Panel), the hearing panel recommended
  Respondent be sanctioned to a ninety-day definite suspension from the practice
  of law and be required to pay the costs of the proceedings.Â  Due to the gravity
  of Respondentâ€™s misconduct, we believe a harsher sanction is warranted.Â  After
  we issued our original opinion suspending Respondent for six months and ordering
  him to pay the costs of the proceedings, Disciplinary Counsel petitioned for
  rehearing.Â  We deny the petition for rehearing, withdraw our original opinion
  in this matter, and substitute it with this opinion which corrects a single
  factual statement that Respondent gave testimony to Disciplinary Counsel
  pursuant to a Notice to Appear and Subpoena rather than appearing as the â€œsole
  witness for a hearing conducted by disciplinary counsel before an investigative
  panel.â€
FACTS
On
  October 5, 2004, Client was involved in an automobile accident in which she
  sustained injuries.Â  Three days later, Client sought to retain Respondent to
  represent her to recover for her injuries and property damage.Â  During the
  initial meeting, Client signed a retainer agreement which stated in part, â€œI
  authorize my attorney to receive settlement checks on my behalf, endorse my
  name and deposit same for distribution.â€ 
In the latter part
  of July 2005, Respondent negotiated a settlement with GEICO in the amount of
  $5,500.Â  In a letter dated August 3, 2005, GEICO submitted a Release to
  Respondent and referenced a settlement check.Â  According to the letter, the
  settlement check dated August 3, 2005, had been sent under a separate cover. Â The
  letter instructed Respondent to hold all funds in escrow until Respondentsâ€™
  clients had signed and returned the Release to GEICO.Â  The Release and
  settlement check were to be signed by Client and her husband.Â  Clientâ€™s husband
  was not represented by Respondent and had never accompanied his wife to any of
  her meetings with Respondent.Â Â  Upon receipt of the check, Respondent endorsed
  it by signing his name, Clientâ€™s name, and her husbandâ€™s name.Â  Respondent
  deposited the check into his trust account and then disbursed his legal fees
  from the settlement proceeds and transferred the amount into his operating
  account.Â  
On August 22, 2005,
  Client met with Respondent who informed her that the case was closed and there
  was nothing else that could be done despite Clientâ€™s complaints that she was
  still in pain and receiving medical treatment. Client expressed dissatisfaction
  with the settlement and ceased any further contact with Respondent.Â  In
  December 2005, Respondentâ€™s office contacted Client in a failed attempt to get
  Client to pick up her settlement check. 
 In May 2006, Client
  retained another attorney (Attorney) to represent her in a legal malpractice
  action against Respondent and to further pursue her personal injury claim.Â 
  During Attorneyâ€™s investigation of the personal injury case, she discovered
  from GEICO that a Release had not been signed.Â Â Â  Because Respondent had
  retained the settlement proceeds, Attorney corresponded in writing with him
  requesting that he return the proceeds to GEICO in order that she could settle
  Clientâ€™s case.Â  In his responses, Respondent claimed that Client had authorized
  him to settle the case and he was not required to return the funds.Â  Respondent
  also challenged Attorneyâ€™s allegation that Client had an additional claim and
  implied that such a claim would be fraudulent. 
Ultimately,
  Respondent returned the settlement proceeds to GEICO less his fee of $1,879.75.Â 
  Following the return of the funds, Attorney negotiated a settlement of $15,000
  from GEICO less the fees retained by Respondent.Â  Attorney also settled with
  State Farm, Clientâ€™s insurance carrier, for $50,000, which represented her
  underinsured coverage.Â  This settlement took into account the medical bills
  that Client acquired after she terminated her representation with Respondent,
  which included a rotator cuff surgery in September 2005 for an injury
  attributed to the October 2004 automobile accident.Â  
Due
  to Respondentâ€™s conduct, Client filed a Complaint against Respondent with the
  ODC.Â  On May 25, 2006, ODC notified Respondent regarding the investigation of Clientâ€™s
  Complaint.Â  Respondent filed a response to the notice on June 22, 2006.Â  On
  November 30, 2006, Respondent gave testimony to Disciplinary Counsel pursuant
  to a Notice to Appear and Subpoena.
Based
  on its investigation, the investigative panel authorized formal charges against
  Respondent.Â  The ODC filed formal charges against Respondent on March 22,
  2007.Â  In his Response to the charges, Respondent admitted he:Â  (1) had
  negotiated the settlement on behalf of Client; and (2) endorsed the settlement
  check with his name and Clientâ€™s name.Â  Because he believed that Client had
  authorized him to settle her case, he denied any misconduct.Â  Although he
  neither admitted nor denied signing Clientâ€™s husbandâ€™s name, he admitted that
  he deposited the settlement check in his trust account and transferred the
  amount of his legal fees into his operating account.Â  He further admitted that
  at the time of the disbursement of the legal fees Client had not signed any
  type of settlement or disbursement sheet.
At
  the hearing before the Panel, the following witnesses were presented:Â  Client, Clientâ€™s
  husband, Attorney, and another witness (Witness A)[1] who recounted Respondentâ€™s actions.Â  
Respondent
  gave a different account of his representation of Client.Â  Respondent, a sole
  practitioner, testified he had practiced law for thirty-one years during which
  time he had handled personal injury cases. Â In terms of representing Client,
  Respondent testified he felt Client was â€œanxious to settleâ€ given she
  frequently called his office to inquire about a settlement.Â Â  Because he
  believed that Client was released from medical treatment on July 8, 2005[2],
  he pursued a settlement with GEICO in the latter part of July 2005.Â  According
  to Respondent, Client authorized him to settle her case for $6,000.Â Â 
  Respondent claimed he entered into an agreement with GEICO to settle the case
  after several failed attempts to consult with Client regarding a settlement.Â 
  He further stated that in all of his years of practice he had never settled a
  claim without his clientâ€™s permission. 
Respondent
  admitted that after receiving the settlement check from GEICO he signed Clientâ€™s
  name to the check.Â  Although he could not specifically recall signing Clientâ€™s
  husbandâ€™s name to the check, he testified that if he signed the check it was
  done without a fraudulent intent. Respondent further admitted he deposited the
  settlement check in his trust account and transferred the amount of his legal
  fees into his operating account.Â  Respondent believed this conduct was
  permissible and not in violation of GEICOâ€™s instructions because he received
  the settlement check prior to receiving GEICOâ€™s letter.Â  Respondent further
  testified he did not believe any of his conduct, while representing Client, was
  unethical.
On
  cross-examination, Respondent admitted he sent a medical release to Clientâ€™s
  orthopedist on August 22, 2005, in which he requested Clientâ€™s medical records
  from August 1, 2005.Â  Respondent was unable to explain why he made this request
  after he entered into a settlement agreement with GEICO in July 2005.Â Â Â   In
  terms of endorsing the settlement check, Respondent conceded that he was not
  authorized to sign for Clientâ€™s husband; however, he claimed he did so because
  he was concerned about losing the check before it was properly endorsed.Â  
After the hearing,
  the Panel found Respondent engaged in misconduct in violation of the following
  Rules of Professional Conduct,Â  Rule 407, SCACR: Â Rule 1.1, RPC (Competence);
  Rule 1.2, RPC (Scope of Representation; Allocation of Authority between Client
  and Lawyer); Rule 1.4, RPC (Communication); Rule 1.5 (Fees); Rule 1.15, RPC
  (Safekeeping Clientâ€™s Property); and Rules 8.4(d) and (e), RPC (Misconduct).Â 
  The Panel recommended that Respondent be suspended for a period of ninety days
  and pay the costs of the proceedings. 
DISCUSSION
Although
  Respondent raises eleven exceptions to the Panelâ€™s report, we believe
  Respondent is essentially challenging the Panelâ€™s:Â  (1) factual findings; (2)
  decision regarding the exclusion of certain testimony; and (3) imposition of a
  ninety-day suspension.
â€œThis Court has the
  sole authority to discipline attorneys and to decide the appropriate sanction
  after a thorough review of the record.â€Â  In re Thompson, 343 S.C. 1, 10,
  539 S.E.2d 396, 401 (2000).Â  â€œAlthough this Court is not bound by the findings
  of the Panel and Committee, these findings are entitled to great weight,
  particularly when the inferences to be drawn from the testimony depend on the
  credibility of witnesses.â€Â  In re Marshall, 331 S.C. 514, 519, 498
  S.E.2d 869, 871 (1998).Â Â  â€œHowever, this Court may make its own findings of fact
  and conclusions of law.â€Â  Id.Â  Furthermore, a disciplinary violation
  must be proven by clear and convincing evidence.Â  In re Greene, 371 S.C.
  207, 216, 638 S.E.2d 677, 682 (2006).
I. Factual Findings
In
  terms of the Panelâ€™s factual findings, Respondent contends the Panel erred in:Â 
  (1) finding that his testimony was not credible; (2) placing emphasis on the
  fact that he settled the case for less than Client had authorized; (3) finding
  he violated GEICOâ€™s instructions to hold the settlement proceeds in escrow
  until the Release was signed by Client and her husband; (4) finding he did not
  have proper authorization from Client to settle her case; (5) finding he failed
  to present Client with any settlement or disbursement statement; (6) placing
  emphasis on the fact that he obtained medical releases from Client after the
  case was settled; and (7) making a statement that Respondentâ€™s failure to
  promptly return the settlement proceeds to GEICO after requested to do so by Attorney
  caused the Panel â€œgrave concern.â€ 
The Panel prefaced
  its decision with a specific finding that Respondentâ€™s testimony was not
  credible.Â  Because the inferences drawn from testimony in the record depended
  largely on the credibility of the witnesses, we believe this finding by the
  Panel is significant in terms of assessing Respondentâ€™s exceptions to the
  Panelâ€™s ultimate decision. 
Deferring to the
  Panel on its credibility determination, we find there is evidence to support
  each of the factual findings challenged by Respondent.Â  First, Client denied
  ever authorizing Respondent to settle her case for $6,000.Â  Thus, the Panelâ€™s
  emphasis on the fact that Respondent settled Clientâ€™s claim for less than
  $6,000 does not establish error on the part of the Panel as argued by
  Respondent.Â  Instead, the Panelâ€™s finding was merely intended to support its
  determination as to Respondentâ€™s credibility.Â  
Secondly,
  Respondent admitted that he endorsed the settlement check, deposited it into
  his trust account, and transferred his legal fees to his operating account.Â 
  Clearly, Respondentâ€™s actions were in direct violation of the instructions by
  GEICO that Respondent retain the settlement proceeds in his trust account until
  the parties signed and returned the Release.Â  Even if, as Respondent contends,
  the settlement check was received prior to the GEICO instruction letter, this
  would not negate Respondentâ€™s misconduct.Â  Once he received the letter,
  Respondent should have withdrawn his legal fees from the operating account and
  transferred them back to his trust account.Â  Furthermore, Respondent was aware
  on August 22, 2005, that Client did not intend to sign the GEICO release.Â 
  Thus, per GEICOâ€™s instruction, Respondent should have returned his legal fees
  to his trust account until the matter was resolved.Â  As of the date of the
  Panel hearing on June 27, 2007, Respondent still retained the amount of his
  legal fees in his operating account.Â  
Thirdly, again
  deferring to the Panelâ€™s credibility determination, there is evidence to
  support the Panelâ€™s finding that Respondent did not have proper authorization
  to settle Clientâ€™s case.Â  Respondentâ€™s reliance on his retainer agreement to
  support his decision to settle the case is misplaced.Â  The terms of the
  retainer agreement only authorized Respondent to receive a settlement check and
  endorse a clientâ€™s name if the client agreed to the proposed settlement.Â  Here,
  Client adamantly denied authorizing Respondent to settle her case.Â  
Fourthly, there is
  evidence to support the Panelâ€™s finding that Client had not signed any
  settlement or disbursement statement.Â  Respondent admitted that Client never
  signed a release for the settlement check.Â  Moreover, even at their last
  meeting on August 22, 2005, Client expressed dissatisfaction with the settlement,
  did not sign any documents, and ceased all further contact with Respondent.Â  
Fifthly, there is
  evidence to support the Panelâ€™s finding that Respondent sought to obtain
  medical releases for Clientâ€™s records after the case was settled.Â  Respondent
  believes this finding was irrelevant to a determination of misconduct.Â  We
  believe the Panelâ€™s finding was intended to establish that Respondent was not a
  credible witness.Â  Respondent never adequately explained his decision to seek a
  medical release to obtain Clientâ€™s medical records in August 2005 after he had
  settled the case in July 2005.Â  According to Respondent, he claimed he had in
  his possession all of Clientâ€™s medical records at the time he entered into the
  settlement agreement.Â  Respondent also testified that he informed Client on
  August 22, 2005, that the case had been settled and nothing could be done
  regarding any additional medical treatment for her injuries.Â  Thus, the fact
  that he requested additional medical records after the settlement and this
  meeting created a discrepancy in Respondentâ€™s testimony and would again draw
  into question his credibility.Â  
Finally, the Panel
  was justified in expressing concern over the fact that Respondent declined to
  promptly return the settlement proceeds to GEICO when requested by Attorney.Â 
  Respondent admitted that Client never signed a settlement release.Â  He also
  knew of the correspondence between Attorney and GEICO regarding a potential
  settlement of Clientâ€™s claim.Â  Therefore, Respondent was aware that Clientâ€™s
  personal injury claim with GEICO had not been finalized.Â Â  Despite this
  knowledge, Respondent delayed returning the funds to GEICO.Â  Additionally,
  Respondent never relinquished the amount of his attorney fees even though he
  failed to procure a final settlement for Client.Â  Respondentâ€™s failure to
  promptly return the entire amount of the settlement proceeds impeded Attorneyâ€™s
  progress in pursuing Clientâ€™s claim with GEICO.
II. Exclusion of Testimony
Respondent contends the Panel erred in ruling that
  neither he nor his proposed witness (Witness B) could testify regarding
  problems Respondent encountered with Attorney prior to his representation of Client.
At the start of the
  hearing, Respondentâ€™s counsel indicated that he intended to call Witness B, a
  former client of Attorneyâ€™s and a member of Respondentâ€™s office staff who was
  also his client.Â  According to Respondentâ€™s counsel, Witness B was to testify
  regarding the â€œbad bloodâ€ that existed between Respondent and Attorney prior to
  the Client matter.Â  Counsel also intended to elicit testimony from Witness B
  regarding a grievance she had filed against Attorney.Â  Disciplinary counsel
  objected to the admission of this testimony on the ground it was irrelevant to
  a determination of Respondentâ€™s alleged misconduct.Â  After hearing arguments
  from counsel, the Panel ruled that Respondentâ€™s counsel could not present any
  testimony regarding a grievance against Attorney and needed to limit the
  testimony to only the interactions between Attorney and Respondent regarding
  the Client matter.
Unless provided otherwise in a specific rule, the
  South Carolina Rules of Evidence for non-jury civil matters and the South
  Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure apply to lawyer disciplinary proceedings.Â  Rule
  413, SCACR; Rule 9, RLDE.Â  We hold the Panel properly limited the proposed
  testimony on the ground that it was not relevant.Â  See Rule 401, SCRE (â€œâ€˜Relevantâ€™ evidence means evidence having any tendency
  to make the existence of any fact that is of consequence to the determination
  of the action more probable or less probable than it would be without the
  evidence.â€); Rule 402, SCRE (â€œAll relevant evidence is admissible, except as
  otherwise provided by the Constitution of the United States, the Constitution
  of the State of South Carolina, statutes, these rules, or by other rules
  promulgated by the Supreme Court of South Carolina. Â Evidence which is not
  relevant is not admissible.â€).Â  Because the Panel was only considering the
  formal charges against Respondent, the testimony presented was properly
  confined to Respondentâ€™s representation of Client.Â  Furthermore, given that Attorney
  was called as a witness, Respondentâ€™s counsel was able to attack her
  credibility and establish any potential bias or prejudice she may have had
  against Respondent. 
III. Ninety-Day Suspension
Finally, Respondent challenges the Panelâ€™s
  recommendation of a ninety-day suspension.Â  He contends the recommendation was
  not warranted because: (1) his endorsement of Clientâ€™s husbandâ€™s name on the
  GEICO settlement check was â€œeither harmless error, or such an error as should
  not cause a suspension of his license;â€ and (2) the evidence did not support
  the Panelâ€™s findings that he committed several serious breaches of ethical
  conduct in violation of the Rules of Professional Conduct. 
A.
In its report, the
  Panel concluded that Respondent violated the following Rules of Professional
  Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR: Â Rule 1.1, RPC (â€œA lawyer shall provide competent
  representation to a client. Competent representation requires the legal
  knowledge, skill, thoroughness and preparation reasonably necessary for the
  representation.â€); Rule 1.2, RPC (â€œSubject to paragraphs (c) and (d), a lawyer
  shall abide by a clientâ€™s decisions concerning the objectives of representation
  and, as required by Rule 1.4, shall consult with the client as to the means by
  which they are to be pursued. Â A lawyer may take such action on behalf of the
  client as is impliedly authorized to carry out the representation. Â A lawyer
  shall abide by a clientâ€™s decision whether to make or accept an offer of
  settlement of a matter.â€); Rule 1.4, RPC (providing that a lawyer shall keep
  the client informed and consult with the client regarding means by which
  clientâ€™s objectives are to be accomplished); Rule 1.5, RPC (stating that â€œ[u]pon
  conclusion of a contingent fee matter, the lawyer shall provide the client with
  a written statement stating the outcome of the matter and, if there is a
  recovery, showing the remittance to the client and the method of its
  determinationâ€); Rule 1.15, RPC (providing that a lawyer shall: Â safeguard
  clientâ€™s property; deposit unearned legal fees into client trust account; and
  render full accounting regarding clientâ€™s property); Rule 8.4(d), RPC (stating
  it is professional misconduct for a lawyer to â€œengage in conduct involving
  dishonesty, fraud, deceit or misrepresentationâ€); and Rule 8.4(e), RPC (stating
  it is professional misconduct for a lawyer â€œengage in conduct that is
  prejudicial to the administration of justiceâ€).
We hold there was
  clear and convincing evidence that Respondent violated each of the above-listed
  Rules of Professional Conduct.Â  Deferring to the credibility determination of
  the Panel, Client testified she never authorized Respondent to settle her
  case.Â  Yet, Respondent settled Clientâ€™s claim without her consent and despite
  the knowledge that she was still receiving medical treatment for her injuries.Â 
  We find this conduct was in violation of Rule 1.1 (Competence); Rule 1.2 (Scope
  of Representation; Allocation of Authority between Client and Lawyer); and Rule
  1.4 (Communication).Â  Furthermore, Respondent engaged in fraudulent conduct in
  violation of Rule 8.4(d) when he signed Clientâ€™s husbandâ€™s name to the
  settlement check without his consent and without an agreement to represent
  him.Â  In terms of Respondentâ€™s handling of the settlement proceeds,
  Respondentâ€™s decision to negotiate the settlement check in violation of GEICOâ€™s
  instructions and to disburse his legal fees to his operating account
  constitutes a violation of Rule 1.5 (procedure lawyer should follow after
  conclusion of contingent fee matter) and Rule 1.15 (safekeeping clientâ€™s
  property).Â  Finally, Respondentâ€™s failure to promptly return the entire amount
  of the settlement proceeds to GEICO prevented Attorney from expeditiously
  pursuing Clientâ€™s personal injury claim; therefore, we find this conduct was in
  violation of Rule 8.4(e) (conduct which is prejudicial to the administration of
  justice).Â  Although not listed by the Panel, we also find this conduct violated
  Rule 1.16(d) (â€œUpon termination of representation, a lawyer shall take steps to
  the extent reasonably practicable to protect a clientâ€™s interests, such as
  giving reasonable notice to the client, allowing time for employment of other
  counsel, surrendering papers and property to which the client is entitled and
  refunding any advance payment of fee or expense that has not been earned or
  incurred. Â The lawyer may retain papers relating to the client to the extent
  permitted by other law. The lawyer may retain a reasonable nonrefundable
  retainer.â€).
B.
With respect to the
  Panelâ€™s recommendation of a ninety-day suspension, there is precedent to
  establish that this sanction is within the range this Court has imposed in the
  past where attorneys have engaged in similar misconduct.Â  However, due to
  Respondentâ€™s egregious conduct and the fact that he has been sanctioned by this
  Court in the past,[3] we find the Panelâ€™s recommendation is inadequate and a harsher sanction is
  warranted.Â  Therefore, we hereby sanction Respondent to a six-month definite
  suspension and order him to pay the costs of the proceedings.Â  See, e.g., In re Nwangaza, 362 S.C. 208, 608 S.E.2d 132 (2005) (finding public
  reprimand was warranted, upon submission of agreement, where attorney
  negotiated personal injury settlement check without clientâ€™s
  consent/endorsement; deposited proceeds into trust account; issued a check for
  clientâ€™s medical provider and withdrew her contingency fees; and failed to
  maintain the appropriate balance in her trust account until the dispute over
  the fees in a domestic matter was resolved); In re Williams, 336 S.C.
  578, 521 S.E.2d 497 (1999) (accepting partiesâ€™ agreement and holding that
  public reprimand was warranted where attorney:Â  failed to properly safeguard
  his clientâ€™s property by neglecting to promptly notify his client of settlement
  and fraudulently endorsing settlement check; failed to use proper accounting
  methods; failed to keep his client reasonably informed about status of case;
  failed to comply with demand for payment; made false statements to the Commission
  on Lawyer Conduct and other party in suit; and created a false Disbursement
  Sheet); In re Belding, 356 S.C. 319, 589 S.E.2d 197 (2003) (finding
  one-year suspension was appropriate sanction where attorney:Â  settled case
  without first obtaining clientâ€™s consent; drafted false documents which
  included names of real lawyers and a judge; failed to inform client regarding
  status of case; and failed to take steps to protect his clientâ€™s interest after
  he attempted to be relieved as counsel following a â€œcharade to conceal his
  mistakesâ€); In re Lewis, 344 S.C. 1, 542 S.E.2d 713 (2001) (holding
  attorneyâ€™s engaging in improper banking practices, misappropriating client
  funds, signing clientsâ€™ names to settlement documents and checks without
  clientsâ€™ knowledge or consent, making false statement to disciplinary counsel,
  and violating financial record keeping warranted disbarment); In re Ring,
  320 S.C. 249, 464 S.E.2d 328 (1995) (concluding sanction of disbarment
  warranted where:Â  attorney settled case without clientâ€™s authorization; forged
  clientâ€™s signature; failed to keep client informed or respond to clientâ€™s
  inquiries; misappropriated client funds; terminated representation without
  taking steps to protect clientâ€™s interests; issued a bad check; and failed to
  cooperate in investigation); In re Smith, 310 S.C. 449, 427 S.E.2d 634
  (1992) (holding disbarment was appropriate sanction where attorney:Â  entered
  into settlement without clientâ€™s consent and negotiated settlement check by
  forging clientâ€™s signature; improperly handled client funds; failed to deliver
  property to client; failed to notify client of receiving funds in which client
  had an interest; made false statements to third party and Board; failed to
  cooperate with investigation; failed to competently and diligently represent
  clients; and improperly disclosed client confidence).
CONCLUSION
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  In view of the gravity of Respondentâ€™s misconduct, we
  hereby suspend Respondent from the practice of law for six months.Â 
  Additionally, we order Respondent to pay costs associated with this proceeding
  within ninety days of the filing of this opinion.Â  Within fifteen days of this
  opinion, Respondent shall file an affidavit with the Clerk of Court showing
  that he has complied with Rule 30 of Rule 413, SCACR.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  DEFINITE
  SUSPENSION. 
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  TOAL,
  C.J., MOORE, WALLER, PLEICONES and BEATTY, JJ., concur.
  


[1]Â  Â Witness A, who worked for Respondent as an
  administrative assistant during the Client matter, testified she had been
  present when Respondent returned phone calls to Client.Â  She further testified
  she spoke with Client several times a week regarding her case.Â Â  Additionally,
  she claimed Client had told her that she had been released from her doctor
  prior to August 2005.Â  However, Witness A stated Client never told her that she
  wanted to settle her case. 
[2]Â Â  Respondent offered into evidence a message from his
  office phone log on July 8, 2005, stating that Client was released from the
  doctor and ready to proceed. Â Respondent claimed to have Clientâ€™s medical bills
  prior to entering into the agreement with GEICO. 
[3]Â  See In re White, 328 S.C. 88, 492
  S.E.2d 82 (1997) (holding public reprimand was warranted for attorneyâ€™s
  improperly retaining client file, ex parte communication with the court, and
  commingling personal funds with client trust funds).

title: State v. McGrier
description: We reverse the circuit court's order revoking six months for Appellant's violation of the Community Supervision Program.
text:
<!--
