-->



THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        Matthew A.
          Giannini, Sr., Personal Representative for the Estate of Deborah Jane
          Giannini, deceased; Tracy Golden and Roderic R. Bradley, Respondents/Appellants, 
        v.
        South Carolina
          Department of Transportation, Appellant/Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
  Â J. Ernest Kinard, Jr., Circuit Court
Judge

Opinion No.Â  26508
  Heard November 14, 2007 - Filed June 23,
2008Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Andrew
          F. Lindemann, of Davidson, Morrison & Lindemann, Frank B. McMaster and John
          Gregg McMaster, both of Tompkins & McMaster, all of Columbia, for
          Appellant-Respondent.
        Charles
          L. Henshaw, Jr., of Furr, Henshaw & Ohanesian, Jeffrey Scott Holcombe, of
          McDougall & Self, Robert C. Ashley, of Ormand, Ashley & Gibbons, and
          Sherod H. Eadon, Jr., of Lee, Eadon, Isgett & Popwell, all of Columbia, for
          Respondents-Appellants.
      
    
  


JUSTICE
  WALLER:Â  These consolidated appeals arise out of tort claims actions filed
  by the plaintiffs against the South Carolina Department of Transportation
  (SCDOT).Â  The jury returned verdicts in favor of the plaintiffs; the trial
  court reduced the verdicts pursuant to the S.C. Tort Claims Act, S.C. Code Ann.
  Â§ 15-78-10 et seq.Â Â  The plaintiffs and SCDOT appeal.Â  We affirm.Â  
FACTS
These
  cases arise out of an automobile accident which occurred on January 4, 2000, on
  Interstate 77 (I-77) in Columbia, between the Boyden Arbor overpass and Percival Road.Â  At 3:10 p.m., a Ford Expedition driven by Barry Harp, while heading north on
  I-77, hydroplaned and crossed the center median into the southboundÂ  lanes,
  striking cars driven by Deborah Giannini, and Tracey Golden.Â  Roderic Bradley
  was a passenger in the vehicle driven by Golden.Â  Giannini was killed; Golden
  and Bradley suffered serious bodily injuries.Â  
The
  plaintiffs filed tort claim actions alleging SCDOT was negligent in failing to
  install median barriers which could have prevented Harpâ€™s vehicle from crossing
  over into the southbound lane of traffic.Â Â  SCDOT answered and claimed it was
  immune from liability under the S.C. Tort Claims Act, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-78-60
  (15).Â  The trial court denied SCDOTâ€™s motions for directed verdict, and the
  case proceeded to trial.Â  The jury returned verdicts of $1.5 million dollars to
  the estate of Giannini, $745,000 to Golden, and $645,000 to Bradley.Â  SCDOT
  filed motions for judgment notwithstanding the verdict (JNOV) and to reduce the
  verdicts in accordance with the statutory limitations of liability set forth by
  the Tort Claims Act.Â  The trial court denied JNOV but reduced the verdicts to
  $200,000 for each plaintiff.Â  SCDOT and the plaintiffs appeal.Â Â 

ISSUES
SCDOT Appeal:

  1.Â  Did the trial court err in denying SCDOTâ€™s motions for
    directed verdict and JNOV?
    2.Â  Did the trial court err in refusing to instruct the jury
    regarding the non-taxability of their verdict?

Plaintiffsâ€™
  Appeal:

  1.Â  Does the Tort Claims Actâ€™s limitation of recovery to $600,000
    total per occurrence violate equal protection?
    2.Â  Did the General Assembly violate the â€œone subjectâ€ rule of
    S.C. Const., Art. III, Â§ 17 by â€œlogrollingâ€ or â€œbobtailingâ€ the reenactment of
    statutory caps in the 1994 and 1997 Appropriations Acts?Â  

Plaintiff Gianniniâ€™s Appeal:

  1.Â  Did the trial court err in apportioning the $600,000 verdict
    equally among the three plaintiffs, as opposed to apportioning it in proportion
    to the verdicts?

1.Â Â  SCDOT APPEAL - JNOV
SCDOT
  contends the trial court erred in denying its motions for a directed verdict
  and JNOV on numerous grounds.Â  It contends a) it did not owe a duty to install
  a median barrier where the accident occurred, b) it was entitled to
  design/discretionary immunity, and c) there is no evidence that the absence of
  a median barrier was the proximate cause of the accident.Â Â  We disagree.Â  We
  find these matters were properly submitted to a jury.Â  
Initially,
  SCDOT asserts that S.C. Code Â§ 15-78-60(15) shields it from liability.Â  Section
  15-78-60(15) sets forth exceptions to the stateâ€™s waiver of sovereign immunity,
  stating, in pertinent part, that a governmental entity is not liable for loss
  resulting from: 

  (15) absence, condition or malfunction. . . of any. . . median
    barrier unless the absence, condition, or malfunction is not corrected by the
    governmental entity responsible for its maintenance within a reasonable time
    after actual or constructive notice. . . . Nothing in this item gives rise to
    liability arising from a failure of any governmental entity to initially place
    any of the above signs, signals, warning devices, guardrails, or median
    barriers when the failure is the result of a discretionary act of the
    governmental entity. . . .Â  Governmental entities are not liable for the design
    of highways and other public ways. . . .Â  

SCDOTÂ 
  contends it owed no duty because its actions were the result of the design of
  the highway, such that it is immune from liability.Â Â  It cites Summer v.
    Carpenter, 328 S.C. 36, 492 S.E.2d 55 (1997), in support of its
  contention.Â Â  Summer is inapposite.Â  In Summer, we held SCDOTâ€™s
  insertion of wedging to correct bumps in an intersection which was under
  construction was essentially a claim of defective construction, such that the
  plaintiff had no claim because SCDOT was entitled to design immunity.Â  The
  rationale for our holding in Summer was that the intersection was still
  in the process of being constructed. 
Unlike Summer, the plaintiffs here claim that SCDOT failed
  to take proper measures after notice of an existing hazard.Â  Here, the portion
  of I-77 where the accident occurred was built in 1995, and there had been
  several crossover accidents within two miles of this accident in which two
  people had been killed; the accidents had been publicized by local media.Â  This
  is not a claim of defective construction but, rather, one of failure to take
  corrective action subsequent to notice of a defect.Â  This case is more
  analogous to Wooten v. SCDOT, 333 S.C. 464, 511 S.E.2d 355 (1999).Â  
In Wooten, we affirmed the Court of Appealsâ€™ ruling that
  although SCDOT has design immunity, such immunity does not extend to
  maintenance issues after the DOT has notice of a hazardous condition.Â  333 S.C.
  at 467-468, 511 S.E.2d at 357.Â  In Wooten, the plaintiffs claimed SCDOT
  was negligent in failing to provide traffic lights at an intersection which would
  allow a pedestrian ample time to cross the street.Â  The Court of Appeals held
  that although DOT initially had design immunity, such immunity was not
  â€œperpetual.â€Â  The Court of Appeals held that once DOT had notice the
  intersection was hazardous, it was no longer immune from liability.Â  328 S.C.
  36, 492 S.E.2d 55 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  On appeal, this Court affirmed as modified,
  adopting the trial courtâ€™s ruling that the immunity provision regarding signs
  and signals was the more specific one applicable to the case, such that a jury
  issue was presented as to whether SCDOT was liable.Â  Wooten v. SCDOT,
  333 S.C. at 468-469, 511 S.E.2d at 357-358 (1999).Â  
Accordingly,
  we find the trial[1] court properly denied SCDOTâ€™s motions for directed verdict and JNOV on the
  issue of whether it breached a duty to the Plaintiffs in failing to install
  median barriers after notice of cross over accidents along that stretch of
  I-77.Â  
SCDOT also
  asserts it was entitled to a directed verdict as there was no evidence the
  absence of a median barrier proximately caused the accident.Â  We disagree.Â  
Plaintiffs
  presented the deposition testimony of Darcy Sullivan, a highway transportation
  engineer.Â  Sullivan testified that it was feasible to install three-cable
  median barriers prior to January 2000, and that such a barrier would have
  entrapped or redirected the tires of a car hitting it.Â  When asked if he had an
  opinion to a reasonable degree of engineering certainty whether the collision
  in this case most probably could have been prevented, he testified, â€œI think it
  is highly likely that the crossover would have been prevented.Â  Certainly, the
  vehicle would have been redirected to some extent.Â  And although there may have
  been some subsequent crash, it would not have been the crash that occurred.Â 
  The trajectory of the Harp vehicle would have been modified enough that it
  simply would not have happened as it did.â€Â  
This
  evidence was sufficient to submit the issue to the jury, and any defects in
  Sullivanâ€™s testimony were matters of weight for the jury.Â  Fields v. Regâ€™l
    Med. Ctr. Orangeburg, 363 S.C. 19, 25, 609 S.E.2d 506, 509 (2005)
  (qualification of an expert witness and the admissibility of the expertâ€™s
  testimony are matters within the trial courtâ€™s sound discretion); State v. White,
  372 S.C. 364, 642 S.E.2d 607 (Ct. App. 2007)(defects in the amount and quality
  of the expertâ€™s education or experience go to the weight to be accorded the
  expertâ€™s testimony and not to its admissibility).Â Â  JNOV was properly denied on
  the issue of proximate cause.

2.Â  JURY INSTRUCTION ON TAXABILITY
SCDOT next
  asserts the trial court committed error in refusing to instruct the jury that
  any award it gave would not be subject to income taxes, and that it was not to
  consider taxes in fixing the amount of an award.Â  It cites for this proposition
  a 1952 Missouri case, Dempsey v. Thompson, 363 Mo. 339, 251 S.W.2d 42
  (1952).Â  Dempsey is not controlling here.
We find
  no South Carolina cases suggesting that a jury instruction on income tax
  consequences is appropriate.Â Â  On the contrary, such a charge is prohibited by
  the collateral source rule.Â  See e.g., New Found Baptist Church v.
    Davis, 257 S.C. 443, 186 S.E.2d 247 (1972); Young v. Warr, 252 S.C.
  179, 165 S.E.2d 797 (1969) (tortfeasor has no right to any mitigation of
  damages because of payments or compensation received by the injured person from
  a source wholly independent of the wrongdoer); 11 S.C. Juris. Damages Â§
  11 (1992); see 22 Am.Jur.2d Damages Â§Â§ 570-90, at 641-56 (1988)
  (tortfeasor cannot take advantage of payments or services rendered by a
  collateral source for the plaintiff's benefit, irrespective of whether the
  source is an insurance company, an employer, a family member, or other source).Â 
  We find no basis upon which to hold such a charge warranted under S.C. law.[2] 
The
  trial court committed no error in refusing the requested charge.Â  Moreover, we
  find no conceivable prejudice here, in light of the size of the verdicts and
  the fact that the verdicts were reduced in accordance with the Tort Claims Act
  caps.

PLAINTIFFSâ€™ APPEAL: 
1.Â Â Â Â Â Â  EQUAL PROTECTION
Plaintiffs
  Giannini, Golden and Bradley contend the Tort Claims Actâ€™s limitation to a
  $600,000 aggregate verdict violates equal protection.Â  We disagree. 
 The
  jury awarded verdicts of $1.5 million (Giannini estate), $745,000 (Golden), and
  $645,000 (Bradley).Â Â  The trial court reduced the verdicts to a total of
  $600,000 pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-78-120(2), which provides â€œ[e]xcept as
  provided in Section 15-8-120(a)(4), the total sum recovered hereunder arising
  out of a single occurrence shall not exceed six hundred thousand dollars
  regardless of the number of agencies or political subdivisions or claims or
  actions involved.â€Â  
 This
  Court has previously addressed the individual statutory caps as set forth in
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-78-120(a), which provides a limitation on damages to
  $300,000 because of â€œloss arising from a single occurrence regardless of the
  number of agencies or political subdivisions involved.â€Â  In Wright v.
    Colleton County, 301 S.C. 282, 291-292, 391 S.E.2d 564, 570 (1990), we
  upheld the $300,000 cap against an equal protection challenge, stating:

  the limitation bears a reasonable relationship to the legislative
    objectives as expressed in Section 15-78-20(a) of relieving the government from
    hardships of unlimited and unqualified liability and preserving the finite
    assets of governmental entities which are needed for an effective and efficient
    government. The limitations set forth in the statute rest on a reasonable basis
    and are not arbitrary in that the legislature has balanced the needs for
    services and demand for reasonable taxes against the fair reimbursement of
    injured tort victims.Â  Finally, we find that the damage limitation provisions
    apply to similar plaintiffs in a similar manner.

We concluded in Wright that there was no equal protection violation because the same monetary cap
  applies equally to the entire class of plaintiffs.Â  Id.
Plaintiffs
  assert the class here, tort victims injured by the state, are not treated the
  same under the statute, because the dollar amount may vary and be limited by
  the amount of persons injured in an occurrence.Â  We disagree.Â Â  We find the
  limitation accords with the stated legislative purpose of preserving finite
  governmental assets, and treats similar plaintiffs in a similar manner.Â  
As we noted in Foster v. SC Depâ€™t of Transp., 306 S.C. 519,
  413 S.E.2d 31 (1992), the fact that a classification results in some inequity
  does not render it in violation of the Constitution.Â  In Foster, we
  upheld higher liability limits for physicians and dentists against an equal
  protection challenge.Â  
We find
  the Legislatureâ€™s aggregate limitation on liability is supported by a rational
  basis such that there is no equal protection violation.Â  Accord Wilson
    v. Gipson, 753 P.2d 1349 (OK 1998) (several children injured and five
  killed in explosion of water heater at a public school; court upheld aggregate
  limitation of $300,000 liability against equal protection challenge, awarding
  $18,221 to parents of children killed, and remainder to injured children);Â  Lee
    v. Colorado Department of Health, 718 P.2d 221 (Colo.1986) (legislative
  decision to limit the public entityâ€™s liability to $150,000 for any injury to
  one person and $400,000 for any injury to two or more persons in a single
  occurrence withstood equal protection).
2.Â Â Â Â Â Â  ONE SUBJECT/BOBTAILING
Giannini,
  Bradley and Golden next assert the Legislatureâ€™s re-enactment of the statutory
  tort claims caps in 1994 and 1997 violate S.C. Const., Art. III Â§ 17 by
  â€œlogrollingâ€ or â€œbobtailingâ€ provisions into an appropriations act.Â  We disagree.
 S.C.
  CONST. Art. III, Â§ 17 requires that â€œEvery Act or resolution having the force
  of law shall relate to but one subject, and that shall be expressed in the
  title.â€Â  
As
  recently noted by this Court:

  The purpose of Article III, Â§ 17 is (1) to apprise the members of
    the General Assembly of the contents of an act by reading the title, (2)
    prevent legislative log-rolling and (3) inform the people of the state of the
    matters with which the General Assembly concerns itself. . . . Article III, Â§
    17 is to be liberally construed so as to uphold an Act if practicable.Â 
    Doubtful or close cases are to be resolved in favor of upholding an Actâ€™s
    validity.Â  Article III, Â§ 17 does not preclude the legislature from dealing
    with several branches of one general subject in a single act. Â It is complied
    with if the title of an act expresses a general subject and the body provides
    the means to facilitate accomplishment of the general purpose. Â However,
    Article III, section 17 requires â€˜the topics in the body of the act [be]
    kindred in nature and hav[e] a legitimate and natural association with the
    subject of the title,â€™ and that the title conveys â€˜reasonable notice of the
    subject matter to the legislature and the public.â€™

Sloan v.
  Wilkins, 362 S.C. 430,
  608 S.E.2d 579 (2005) (emphasis supplied, internal citations omitted).Â 
  Plaintiffs assert the reenactments violate the one-subject rule as they do not
  inherently relate to the raising and spending of tax monies.Â  
We
  recognized in Town of Hilton Head v. Morris, 324 S.C. 30, 484 S.E.2d
  104, 107 (1997) that â€œa measure enacted as part of a general appropriations act
  does not violate Article III, Â§ 17, if it reasonably and inherently relates to
  the raising and spending of tax monies.â€Â  See also Keyserling v.
    Beasley, 322 S.C. 83, 470 S.E.2d 100 (1996) (provisions of appropriations
  act which created negotiating committee to establish new regional radioactive
  waste disposal compact and which repealed statute adopting prior compact were
  related to raising and spending of revenues and, thus, complied with
  one-subject rule); Hercules v. South Carolina Tax Commâ€™n, 274 S.C. 137,
  262 S.E.2d 45 (1980) (statute providing for suspension of the statute of limitations
  on tax assessment if a corporate taxpayer fails to give the Tax Commission
  notice of an IRS examination was germane to the General Appropriations Act in
  which it was contained and thus did not violate the constitutional requirement
  that every act relate to but one subject). 
Here,
  1994 Act No. 497, lists in its title that the act is â€œTO PROVIDE THAT CERTAIN
  PROVISIONS OF SECTIONS 15-78-100 AND 15-78-120 OF THE 1976 CODE ARE REENACTED
  AND MADE RETROACTIVE TO APRIL 5, 1988.â€Â  Further, Part 2, Â§ 107 of the
  Appropriations Act amends the Uniform Contribution Among Joint Tortfeasors Act
  to make it inapplicable to government agencies, and reinstates the Tort Claims
  Caps set forth in Â§ 15-78-120(a)(1).Â  The 1997 Appropriations Act, 1997 Act No.
  155, Part II, Â§ 55, similarly reenacts the $500,000 cap set forth in Â§
  15-78-120(a)(2).Â Â  The statutory reenactments reasonably and inherently relate
  to the raising and spending of tax monies.Â  Town of Hilton Head v. Morris.Â 
  Accordingly, reenactment of the caps does not violate Article III, Â§ 17.Â  
GIANNINIâ€™S
  APPEAL: 
1.Â  APPORTIONMENT OF VERDICT
Finally,
  Giannini asserts the trial court erred in apportioning the verdict equally
  among the Plaintiffs, rather than apportioning it in accordance with the
  verdicts awarded to each plaintiff.Â  
As
  noted, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-78-120(a)(1) limits an individualâ€™s recovery against
  a government agency to $300,000 for a loss arising from a single occurrence.Â 
  Section 15-78-120(a)(2) further limits the total sum recoverable from a single
  occurrence to $600,000 regardless of the number of agencies or political
  subdivisions or claims or actions involved.Â  The trial court determined that,
  since each of the verdicts exceeded $300,000, each plaintiffâ€™s verdict would
  each be reduced to $200,000.Â  
We find
  no error in the trial courtâ€™s apportionment.Â  If the Legislature had intended
  for the $600,000 aggregate cap to be divided in proportion to the verdicts
  awarded to each plaintiff, it could have said so.Â  State v. Curtis, 356
  S.C. 622, 591 S.E.2d 600 (2004) (if Legislature had intended certain result in
  a statute it would have said so).Â Â  Accordingly, the trial courtâ€™s ruling is
  affirmed.Â Â  
AFFIRMED.

MOORE, J.,
  concurs.Â  BEATTY, J., concurring in a separate opinion. Â PLEICONES, J.
  dissenting in a separate opinion in which TOAL, C.J., concurs.

JUSTICE
  BEATTY:Â  I concur in the majority
  opinion; however, I write separately to address the discretionary immunity
  issue.[3]Â Â  
In
  my view, discretionary immunity viability is equal to that of design immunity,
  neither is perpetual. See Wooten ex rel. Wooten v. S.C. Depâ€™t of
    Transp., 333 S.C. 464, 467-68, 511 S.E.2d 355, 357 (1999) (affirming as
  modified the Court of Appealsâ€™ holding that â€œdesign immunity is not perpetual.Â 
  Once the Department of Transportation had notice of a hazardous condition, it
  was no longer immune from liabilityâ€).
Section
  15-78-60(15) affords SCDOT discretionary immunity in the failure to initially place median barriers.Â  This section provides, in pertinent part, that the
  governmental entity is not liable for a loss resulting from:

  (15) absence,
    condition, or malfunction of any sign, signal, warning device,
    illumination device, guardrail, or median barrier unless the absence,
    condition, or malfunction is not corrected by the governmental entity
      responsible for its maintenance within a reasonable time after actual or
      constructive notice. Governmental entities are not liable for the removal
    or destruction of signs, signals, warning devices, guardrails, or median barriers
    by third parties except on failure of the political subdivision to correct them
    within a reasonable time after actual or constructive notice. Nothing in
      this item gives rise to liability arising from a failure of any
    governmental entity to initially place any of the above signs, signals,
    warning devices, guardrails, or median barriers when the failure is
      the result of a discretionary act of the governmental entity.Â  

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-78-60(15)
  (2005)(emphasis added).Â  
â€œDiscretionary immunity is contingent on proof the government
  entity, faced with alternatives, actually weighed competing considerations and
  made a conscious choice using accepted professional standards.â€ Â Wooten ex
    rel. Wooten v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Transp., 333 S.C. 464, 468, 511 S.E.2d 355, 357 (1999).
The
  finite viability of discretionary immunity is evident in the statute itself.Â 
  The statute uses the temporal word initially indicating that the
  immunity for the failure to initially place median barriers terminates after
  notice of a hazardous condition.Â  In other words, SCDOT gets a free pass on the
  initial claim for damages occurring before SCDOT receives notice of a hazardous
  condition if it actually exercised discretion in failing to initially place
  median barriers.Â  After notice, SCDOT is required to remedy the hazardous
  condition within a reasonable time.
I
  agree with the dissent that the exercise of discretion includes the right to be
  wrong but the right to be wrong is not perpetual.Â  The SCDOT exercised
  discretion not to place median barriers when I-77 was constructed and opened to
  traffic.[4]Â 
  SCDOT is entitled to immunity for that decision because it related to the initial placement of median barriers.Â  Subsequent to the initial decision, SCDOT
  received notice of cross-over accidents and the existence of hazardous
  conditions.Â  Once SCDOT was put on notice, the first sentence in section
  15-78-60(15) required SCDOT to correct the condition within a reasonable time. See Steinke v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Labor,
    Licensing & Regulation, 336 S.C. 373, 396, 520 S.E.2d 142, 154 (1999)
  (â€œWhile provisions establishing limitations upon and exemptions from liability
  of a governmental entity must be liberally construed to limit liability, we
  also must presume in construing a statute that the Legislature did not intend
  to perform a futile thing.â€).Â  
Section
  15-78-60(15) does not grant discretionary immunity every time SCDOT attempts to
  correct a hazardous condition.
In
  the instant case, it was up to the jury to determine if SCDOT corrected the
  hazardous condition within a reasonable time as required by section
  15-78-60(15).
I
  would affirm the trial court.

JUSTICE
  PLEICONES:Â Â Â Â Â Â  I respectfully
  dissent.Â  In my opinion, the trial court should have granted SCDOTâ€™s motion for
  directed verdict, and I would not address the other issues raised by the
  parties.[5]
I
  am troubled by the majorityâ€™s analysis of the Tort Claims Actâ€™s immunity
  provisions applicable to SCDOT.Â  First, the majority fails to adequately
  address SCDOTâ€™s claim that it did not owe plaintiffs a duty to install median
  barriers.Â  The majority instead jumps ahead to the immunity issue under the
  Tort Claims Act.Â  While it is clear that SCDOT has a duty to plan, construct,
  maintain, and operate the stateâ€™s highways,[6]Â 
  I believe the majority opinion improperly implies that a duty may arise simply
  because an exception to the Stateâ€™s waiver of sovereign immunity does not exist
  in the Tort Claims Act.Â  Cf. Arthurs ex rel. Est. of Munn v. Aiken
    County, 346 S.C. 97, 105, 551 S.E.2d 579, 583 (2001) (existence of a duty,
  as well as other elements of negligence, must be shown before reaching
  immunities issue under the Tort Claims Act).
Perhaps more
  disconcerting is the majority opinionâ€™s lack of any discussion of discretionary
  immunity.Â  Discretionary immunity is different from design immunity, and SCDOT
  argues it is entitled to both.Â  Design immunity gives SCDOT absolute immunity
  for liability arising from the design of highways and public ways.Â  Wooten
    ex rel. Wooten v. S.C. Dept. of Transp., 333 S.C. 464, 511 S.E.2d 355
  (1999); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-78-60(15).Â  However, design immunity is not
  perpetual, and once the governmental entity receives notice of a hazardous
  condition, it may no longer invoke design immunity as an absolute shield for
  liability.Â  Id.[7]Â 
  Although an entity may lose design immunity, it may still be immune from
  liability if it exercises discretion when faced with actual or constructive
  knowledge of a hazardous condition. 
In Wooten,
  this Court explicitly stated that the design immunity provision of Â§
  15-78-60(15) did not control that case; the more specific clause providing
  discretionary immunity for the initial placement of traffic signals was the
  applicable immunity provision.Â  Likewise, in this case, the pertinent portion
  of Â§ 15-78-60(15) is the part that specifically provides discretionary immunity
  for the initial placement of cable median barriers.Â  The majority appears to
  acknowledge this correlation, but unlike in Wooten, it does not analyze
  whether SCDOTâ€™s actions after it received notice of the dangerous condition
  entitle SCDOT to discretionary immunity.Â  I would hold that SCDOT is entitled
  to discretionary immunity.Â  
Discretionary
  immunity is contingent on proof the government entity, faced with alternatives,
  actually weighed competing considerations and made a conscious choice. Â Further,
  the entity must establish, in weighing the competing considerations and
  alternatives, it utilized accepted professional standards appropriate to
  resolve the issue. Â Strange v. S.C. Dept. of Hwys. & Pub. Transp.,
  314 S.C. 427, 429, 445 S.E.2d 439, 440 (1994). Â The governmental entity bears
  the burden of establishing discretionary immunity as an affirmative defense.Â  Niver
    v. S.C. Dept. of Hwys. & Pub. Transp., 302 S.C. 461, 463, 395 S.E.2d
  728, 730 (Ct. App. 1990).Â  The provisions of the Tort Claims Act that establish
  limitations on and exemptions to the liability of the State must be liberally
  construed in favor of limiting the liability of the State.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  15-78-20(f) (Supp. 2005).
There
  is no question that SCDOT weighed competing economic and environmental
  considerations, in addition to following accepted professional standards
  promulgated by the federal government and the American Assocation of State
  Highway and Transportation Officials (AASHTO), when it decided not to place
  median barriers on I-77 when it opened in 1995.Â  After SCDOT received notice in
  1997 of several median crossover accidents in the vicinity of the accident in
  this case, SCDOT added diagonal yellow lines with raised reflectors to the
  highway shoulders that bordered the median.Â  This was done to reduce crossover
  accidents by decreasing the possibility that motorists would drift into the
  median.
Even
  though the placement of these raised markers significantly decreased the number
  of accidents within a one-mile radius[8] of this accident site, SCDOT began gathering information in 1999 concerning
  median widths, accident history, average daily traffic, etc., in order to
  prioritize and secure funding for installation of median barriers.Â  This
  project was underway when this accident occurred in January 2000, and the first
  median cable barriers were installed by December 2000.Â  The record clearly
  shows that SCDOT constantly weighed its options in an attempt to minimize the
  possibility of crossover accidents on this stretch of I-77.Â  Simply because
  there was disagreement between each sideâ€™s experts as to whether discretion was properly exercised does not preclude discretionary immunity for SCDOT.Â 
  In other words, the exercise of discretion includes the right to be wrong.Â  McCall
    v. Batson, 285 S.C. 243, 329 S.E.2d 741 (1985), superseded by statute as
      recognized in Murphy v. Richland Mem. Hosp., 317 S.C. 560, 455
  S.E.2d 688 (1995).
In
  my opinion, SCDOT was entitled to discretionary immunity because it is
  undisputed that it exercised discretion in maintaining the area of I-77 where
  this accident occurred.Â  SCDOT contemplated its alternatives pursuant to the
  relevant AASHTO regulations and federal standards, and it made a conscious effort
  to keep this interstate as safe as possible in light of its options.Â 
  Accordingly, I would reverse.
TOAL, C.J.,
  concurs.


[1]Â  The dissent is â€œdisconcertedâ€ by our lack of
  discussion of discretionary immunity.Â  It contends SCDOT is entitled to discretionary
  immunity as a matter of law, because there is evidence in the record that SCDOT
  took some action after notice of the accidents.Â  Contrary to the dissentâ€™s
  contention, Â§ 15-78-60(15) provides discretionary immunity only for the
  â€œfailure of any governmental entity to initially place . . . signs, signals,
  warning devices, guardrails, or median barriers when the failure is the result
  of a discretionary act of the governmental entity.â€Â  (Emphasis supplied).Â Â  The
  dissent correctly points out that, in exercising this initial discretion as to
  whether to place median barriers or guard rails, the exercise of such
  discretion includes the right to be wrong.Â Â  McCall v. Batson, 285 S.C.
  243, 329 S.E.2d 741 (1985).Â  
However, the
  exercise of this discretion in the design of highways is not absolute.Â  It is
  subject to the requirement that the â€œabsence, condition, or malfunction [be]
  corrected by the governmental entity responsible for its maintenance within
    a reasonable time after actual or constructive notice.â€ S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  15-78-60(15).Â  (Emphasis supplied). Â Wooten, supra.Â Â  It is undisputed that SCDOT was on notice of fatal
  highway cross over accidents by 1997.Â  It nonetheless failed to install median
  barriers until December 2000, some eleven months after the accident in this
  case.Â Â  
The
  dissent points to the fact that diagonal yellow lines were placed in the
  shoulders of the highway in 1998, thereby evincing an exercise of discretion
  which entitles SCDOT to immunity as a matter of law.Â  On the contrary, when
  cross-examined, SCDOTâ€™s own expert testified that the reason for installation
  of these lines was that the shoulder lane was extremely wide, and the lines
  were placed there to delineate that this was not supposed to be a travel lane
  for drivers.Â  The lines were â€œnot meant to deal with the situation of a car in
  the normal travel lane losing control, leaving the roadway, and crossing in and
  over the median.â€Â  We find a jury question was presented as to whether SCDOT
  properly took corrective action after notice of the crossover accidents was
  properly submitted to the jury.Â  Accord Wooten (whether SCDOT
  complied with appropriate professional standard was at least a jury issue); Pike
    v. SC Depâ€™t of Transp., 343 S.C. 224, 540 S.E.2d 87 (2000) (holding burden
  of persuasion to establish discretionary immunity is on governmental agency,
  and the standard is inherently factual; SCDOT may not shield itself from
  liability as a matter of law by merely creating an issue of fact).Â  
[2]Â  SCDOT cites a United State Supreme Court
  decision upholding such a charge.Â  Norfolk & W. Ry v. Liepelt,
  444 U.S. 490 (1980).Â  However, Liepelt involved a wrongful death action
  brought under Federal Employers' Liability Act in which it was held that
  evidence to show effect of income taxes on decedentâ€™s estimated future earnings
  was admissible at trial.Â  Here, there was no evidence of potential tax
  liability adduced at trial, and the trial court advised SCDOT that if the jury
  asked about it, he would address the taxation issue.Â  
[3] Â SCDOT moved for a directed verdict and JNOV on the ground that it was entitled
  to design immunity and for discretionary immunity under section 15-78-60(15).
[4] Â SCDOT was entitled to both design and discretionary immunity at that time.
[5] While there would be no need to address the remaining issues should we find
  SCDOT should have been granted a directed verdict, I note that I agree with the
  majorityâ€™s conclusions on the remaining questions except for the verdict
  apportionment.Â  I would hold that the trial court erred by not apportioning the
  $600,000 statutory cap in proportion to the actual verdicts returned by the
  jury.Â  Additionally, I believe the enrolled bill rule clearly disposes
  plaintiffsâ€™ bobtailing claim.Â  Med. Socy. of S.C. v. Med. U. of S.C.,
  334 S.C. 270, 278, 513 S.E.2d 352, 356 (1999) (enrolled bill rule provides that
  an act ratified by the General Assembly, approved by the Governor, and enrolled
  in the office of the Secretary of State is conclusively presumed to have been
  properly passed and is not subject to impeachment by evidence outside the act
  to show it was not passed in compliance with law).
[6] S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 57-1-30 (Supp. 2006); Brashier v. S.C. Dept. of Transp.,
  327 S.C. 179, 191, 490 S.E.2d 8, 14 (1997), overruled in part on other
    grounds, Iâ€™On v. Town of Mt. Pleasant, 338 S.C. 406, 526 S.E.2d 716
  (2000).
[7] But cf. Summer v. Carpenter, 328 S.C. 36, 43, 492 S.E.2d 55, 59
  (1997) (holding â€œ[e]ven if the Highway Department was on notice the design of
  the intersection was dangerous, the Highway Department was immune from suit for
  negligent design.â€).Â  Summer can be distinguished by the fact that the
  injury in Summer occurred while the intersection was still under
  construction, thus preserving design immunity.
[8] Given the specific locations involved in tracking highway accidents, it is
  important to note that SCDOT had tracked the accident reports for I-77, and
  between 1995 and 1999, no median cross-over accidents occurred within 1,500
  feet of the site where this accident occurred.

title: American Credit v. Nationwide Mutual Insurance Company
description: This case involves the issue of whether the failure of the insured to utilize the liability insurance proceeds to repair the damaged automobile is a conversion of the automobile within the meaning of the Loss Payable Clause of the policy.
text:
<!--

}
-->



THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        American Credit
          of Sumter, Inc., Appellant,
        v.
        Nationwide
          Mutual Insurance Company, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Sumter County
Â Clifton Newman, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  26509
  Heard February 21, 2008 - Filed June 30,
2008Â  

REVERSED


  
    
      
        Thomas
          E. Player, Jr., of Player & McMillan, of Sumter, for appellant.
        William
          Bailey Woods, of Woods Law Firm, of Lexington, for respondent.
      
    
  

JUSTICE
  MOORE:Â  Appellant (American Credit)
  filed an action claiming respondent (Nationwide) acted in bad faith by failing
  to pay the money due under an insurance policy.Â  Nationwide answered that any
  claim brought by American Credit would be subject to the Loss Payable Clause of
  the policy and that this Clause denies coverage to American Credit.Â  The
  magistrate court granted Nationwideâ€™s motion for a directed verdict and the
  circuit court affirmed.Â  We now reverse.
FACTS
The insured was the
  owner of a 1998 Nissan Altima automobile which was financed by American
  Credit.Â  The automobile was insured with Nationwide for comprehensive and
  collision coverages, with the insured being shown as the policyholder and with
  American Credit as the lienholder.Â  The automobile was involved in a collision
  in Connecticut, which was caused by the driver of another automobile.Â  Damages
  resulted in the amount of $1,801.67.Â  Allstate, the liability insurance carrier
  of the at-fault motorist, paid to the insured a sum of money sufficient to pay
  the costs of repairs to the automobile.Â  The insured failed to have the repairs
  made to the automobile and later defaulted on the loan by American Credit,
  causing the automobile to be repossessed in a damaged condition in the amount of
  $1,801.67.
American
  Credit filed a claim with Nationwide in the amount of $1,307.67[1] and contended it was entitled to payment via the Loss Payable Clause in the
  insurance policy.

  The
    pertinent portion of the Loss Payable Clause states that:
  Protection
    of the lienholderâ€™s financial interest will not be affected by any change in
    ownership of the vehicle insured, nor by any act or omission by any person
    entitled to coverage under this policy.Â  However, protection under this clause
    does not apply in any case of conversion, embezzlement, secretion, or willful
    damaging or destruction, of the vehicle committed by or at the direction of an
    insured.

After the close of
  the evidence in the trial, the magistrate granted Nationwideâ€™s motion for a
  directed verdict.Â  The magistrate found the insured received payment from
  another insurance company for the damage to the automobile and, rather than
  utilizing these funds to repair the automobile, as required under her financing
  contract with American Credit, she converted these funds to her own use.Â  The
  magistrate found that this amounted to a conversion of that portion of the
  automobile which was damaged.Â  As a result of the conversion, the magistrate
  found the protection of the lienholderâ€™s financial interest did not apply under
  the clear language of the Loss Payable Clause.
American Credit
  appealed to the circuit court.Â  The court ruled the magistrate properly granted
  Nationwideâ€™s motion for a directed verdict.Â  The court found the insured
  essentially converted that portion of the automobile that was damaged and paid
  for by Allstate.Â  As a result, any claim American Credit had under the Loss
  Payable Clause was barred by the provision stating that protection under that
  Clause does not apply in a case of conversion committed by or at the discretion
  of the insured.Â  The court stated that when the insured retained the funds she
  received from Allstate, she was essentially altering the condition of the
  automobile and accepting payments to the exclusion of the owner or lienholder.
ISSUE

  Is the failure of the insured to
    utilize the liability insurance proceeds to repair the damaged automobile a
    conversion of the automobile within the meaning of the Loss Payable Clause of
    the policy?

DISCUSSION
A
  loss payable clause is a type of clause used in insurance contracts by which a
  lienholder or mortgagee protects its interests in the insured property.Â  There
  are two types of loss payable clauses:Â  (1) a loss payable or open mortgage
  clause, and (2) a standard clause.Â  Nationwide Mut. Ins. Co. v. Hunt,
  327 S.C. 89, 488 S.E.2d 339 (1997).Â  A lienholderâ€™s ability to recover on an
  insurance policy largely depends on the type of clause used in the insurance
  contract.Â  Id.Â  In general, a loss payable or open mortgage clause
  merely identifies the person or entity that may collect the insurance proceeds
  and an insuredâ€™s misconduct bars recovery by the lienholder.Â  Id.Â  On
  the other hand, under a standard clause, the interests of the lienholder in the
  proceeds of the policy will not be invalidated by the misconduct of the
  insured.Â  Id.
By asserting the
  insuredâ€™s misconduct bars American Credit from recovering under the policy, the
  dissent would find that the Clause at issue is the narrower loss payable or
  open mortgage clause.Â  However, the type of clause involved here is a standard
  clause that contains exceptions, such as the conversion exception, which can
  preclude recovery by the lienholder.Â  Nationwideâ€™s Loss Payable Clause
  specifically states that â€œprotection of the lienholderâ€™s financial interest
  will not be affected by . . . any act or omission by any person entitled to
  coverage under this policyâ€ except â€œin any case of conversionâ€ of the vehicle.Â 
  In other words, Nationwide will not be obligated to make payment to American
  Credit as a result of the insured misappropriating the funds only if such act
  constitutes a conversion of the vehicle by or at the direction of the insured.Â 
  Therefore, contrary to the dissentâ€™s view, a plain reading of the Clause
  extends protection to American Creditâ€™s interest in the automobile
  notwithstanding the insuredâ€™s misconduct, save for the specified exclusion.[2]
The insurance
  policy does not define conversion so we must determine whether the failure of
  the insured to utilize insurance proceeds received from a separate insurer to
  repair the damaged automobile is a conversion of the automobile within the
  meaning of Nationwideâ€™s Loss Payable Clause.
Insurance policies
  are subject to the general rules of contract construction.Â  Century Indem. Co. v. Golden Hills Builders, Inc., 348 S.C. 559, 561 S.E.2d 355 (2002).Â  We must
  give policy language its plain, ordinary, and popular meaning.Â  Id.Â  An insurance policy is to be liberally construed in favor of the insured and
  strictly construed against the insurer.      Kraft v. Hartford Ins. Companies, 279 S.C. 257, 305 S.E.2d 243 (1983).Â 
  Further, exclusions in an insurance
  policy are always construed most strongly against the insurer.Â  Century Indem. Co. v. Golden Hills Builders,
Inc., supra.
We have stated that
  conversion is a wrongful act and have defined conversion as the unauthorized
  assumption in the exercise of the right of ownership over goods or personal
  chattels belonging to another to the exclusion of the ownerâ€™s rights.Â  SSI
    Medical Servs., Inc. v. Cox, 301 S.C. 493, 392 S.E.2d 789 (1990).Â 
  Conversion may arise by some illegal use or misuse, or by illegal detention of
  anotherâ€™s chattel.Â  Id.
The insuredâ€™s
  failure to utilize the insurance proceeds received from the other driverâ€™s
  insurer to repair the damaged automobile is not a conversion.Â  The insured
  owned the automobile at the time she retained the funds that should have been
  used to repair the damaged automobile.Â  The insured had not defaulted on the
  installment contract and the car had not been repossessed; therefore, she was
  still the owner.Â  What is envisioned by the exception to Nationwideâ€™s Loss
  Payable Clause is the conversion of the insured property, that is, the
  automobile.[3]Â 
  No such conversion has occurred here.Â  At all relevant times, the insured has
  not directed or allowed the ownership of the automobile to be assumed by
  another to the exclusion of the insuredâ€™s rights.Â  See SSI Med.
    Servs., Inc. v. Cox, supra (conversion is unauthorized assumption in
  exercise of right of ownership over goods belonging to another to the exclusion
  of the ownerâ€™s rights).Â  See also Foremost Ins. Co. v. Allstate Ins.
    Co., 486 N.W.2d 600 (Mich. 1992) (person cannot convert his own property;
  intentional burning of mobile home did not amount to conversion within meaning of
  loss payable clause); Gibraltar Fin. Corp. v. Lumbermens Mut. Cas. Co.,
  513 N.E.2d 681 (Mass. 1987) (burning of an insured automobile by mortgagor did
  not constitute conversion because, at the time of the arson, no one other than
  the owner/mortgagor had an immediate right to possess the automobile;
  therefore, the mortgageeâ€™s recovery under the policy was not precluded); Nationwide
    Mut. Ins. Co. v. Dempsey, 495 S.E.2d 914 (N.C. App.), review denied,
  502 S.E.2d 847 (N.C. 1998) (automobile policyâ€™s loss payable clause which
  invalidated lienholderâ€™s interest only upon insuredâ€™s conversion of vehicle did
  not apply when vehicle was destroyed by fire allegedly set by insured since
  vehicle was not changed from one purpose to another).
Because the
  exclusion in the insurance policy is to be construed strongly against the
  insurer and Nationwide failed to define conversion to include the
  aforementioned facts, the lower courts erred by finding a conversion had
  occurred when the insured retained the insurance proceeds and failed to repair
  the automobile.Â  See Century Indem. Co. v. Golden Hills Builders,
    Inc., supra (exclusions in an insurance policy are always construed
  most strongly against the insurer).Â  See also Chrysler Credit Corp.
    v. Dairyland Ins. Co., 491 So.2d 402 (La. Ct. App.), writ denied,
  484 So.2d 1178 (La. 1986) (while not determining whether the actions
  constituted conversion, court held where a policy fails to define the term
  â€œlossâ€ it is unclear whether the application by the insured to his personal use
  of the funds received in settlement from the tortfeasorâ€™s insurer is a â€œloss
  caused by conversion,â€ thus relieving the insurer of its obligation to pay the
  claim of the loss payee; the court found, because of the ambiguity, the policy
  must be construed against the insurer).Â  Accordingly,
  the decision of the circuit court is
REVERSED.

TOAL, C.J.,
  WALLER and BEATTY, JJ., concur. PLEICONES, J., dissenting in a separate
opinion.

JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â Â Â Â Â Â  I respectfully dissent and would affirm.Â  In my
  opinion, under the facts of this case, the loss-payable clause does not provide
  American Credit with a right to recover from Nationwide the amount retained by
  the defaulting insured after she received payment from a third-partyâ€™s
  liability carrier.[4]
It has been held
  that an insuredâ€™s misconduct bars recovery by the lienholder under a
  loss-payable clause.Â  Nationwide Mut. Ins. Co. v. Hunt, 327 S.C. 89, 93,
  488 S.C. 339, 341 (1997).Â  Furthermore, the loss-payable clause merely
  identifies the person who may collect the proceeds, and the lienholder stands
  in the insuredâ€™s shoes and is usually subject to the same defenses.Â  Id.Â  
In
  Nationwideâ€™s policy with its insured in this case, the loss-payable clause
  specifically states, â€œThis clause applies to the Comprehensive and Collision
  coverages provided by this policy.â€Â  Because, under the facts of this case,
  Nationwideâ€™s coverage was never triggered, the loss-payable clause is simply
  not involved.Â  Again, the lienholder merely stands in the shoes of the
  insured.Â  Hunt, supra.Â  If Nationwide is not obligated to tender
  payment to its insured, the loss-payable clause does not inure to the benefit
  of American Credit.Â Â Â  This loss-payable clause applies only in the event of a
  valid first-party claim under the policy between the insured and Nationwide.Â 
  American Credit could only receive the benefit of the loss-payable clause
  should Nationwide have tendered payment to its insured without protecting
  American Creditâ€™s rights as a lienholder, or had otherwise participated in some
  way to the derogation of American Creditâ€™s rights.
In
  this case, because there was never a first-party claim, I am at a loss to
  discern why Nationwide is now liable for its insuredâ€™s misapplication of
  proceeds received from the at-fault partyâ€™s carrier.Â  Nationwideâ€™s obligation
  does not extend to insuring American Credit against losses over which
  Nationwide had no control.[5]Â 
  American Credit must look solely to the insured who failed to submit to
  American Credit insurance proceeds from Allstate when she defaulted on the
  loan.[6]
In
  my opinion, the loss-payable clause found in the insurance contract between
  Nationwide and its insured did not protect American Creditâ€™s interest where
  that interest was damaged by the acts of a third-party or by the insured.Â  I
  would affirm.


[1]$1,307.67
  represents the cost of repair of the automobile less the $500 deductible as
provided in the insurance policy. 
[2]Although
  the dissent would find the Loss Payable Clause at issue is the narrower loss
  payable, or open mortgage, clause, the issue the parties asked this Court to
  resolve was not whether American Credit could recover pursuant to the Loss
  Payable Clause, but rather whether the exclusions contained in the Loss Payable
  Clause barred American Creditâ€™s claim.Â  Nationwide has never argued that the
  Clause was the narrower loss payable or open mortgage clause, nor did
  Nationwide assert that any misconduct on behalf of the insured barred
  American Creditâ€™s claim.Â  In fact, in its brief to this Court, Nationwide
  admits that â€œthe policy does provide additional protection to the . . .
  lienholder by indicating that the lienholderâ€™s right will not be affected by
  the acts of the insured.â€Â  This statement clearly indicates that Nationwide
  acknowledged that the Clause provided broader protection to a lienholder.Â  In
  any event, because Nationwide did not argue that this Clause was the narrower
  loss payable or open mortgage clause, this issue is not preserved.Â  See Holy
    Loch Distribs., Inc. v. Hitchcock, 340 S.C. 20, 531 S.E.2d 282 (2000) (to
  preserve issue for appellate review, issue must have been raised to and ruled
upon by the trial court).
[3]The
  exception states:Â  â€œprotection under this clause does not apply in any case of
  conversion . . . of the vehicle committed by or at the direction of the
insured.â€Â  (Emphasis added). 
[4] While I do not believe the interpretation of the
  loss-payable clause controls this case, I disagree with the majorityâ€™s
  statement that the clause be strictly construed against Nationwide in favor of
  American Credit.Â  Nationwideâ€™s failure to define the term â€œconversionâ€ in the
  insuredâ€™s policy does not necessarily require us to apply that term narrowly to
  these facts.Â  The loss-payable clause in this case is not an exclusion of
  coverage for the insured but exists for the benefit of a lienholder who is not
  a party to the insurance contract.
[5] Indeed, there is no indication that Nationwide was ever made aware of the event
which occasioned damage to the vehicle.
[6] Insured was under no obligation to American Credit to repair her vehicle with
  the money paid by Allstate so long as she made payments on the loan from
American Credit.

title: State v. Groome
description: The Court affirmed a circuit court order suppressing evidence obtained as the result of an unconstitutional drivers' license checkpoint.
text:
<!--
body{
font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;
}
-->



THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        The State, Appellant,
        v.
        Eston Groome, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal from Greenville County
Â D. Garrison Hill, Circuit Court Judge

Â Opinion No. 26510
Heard April 15, 2008 - Filed June 30, 2008Â Â Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Attorney
          General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant
          Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and Assistant Attorney General Julie
          M. Thames, all of Columbia, and Solicitor Robert Mills Ariail, of Greenville,
          for Appellant.
        J.
          Falkner Wilkes of Greenville, and James H. Price, III, of Price, Ashmore &
          Beasley, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  


JUSTICE
  PLEICONES:Â  The State appeals a pre-trial circuit court order
  suppressing drugs found after respondent was stopped at a driversâ€™ license
  checkpoint.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
In response to civilian â€œcrime stoppersâ€ tips of
  speeding and drug activity, a â€œDirected Patrol Unitâ€ set up a driversâ€™ license
  checkpoint one evening in Greenville.Â  A â€œDirected Patrol Unitâ€ is a
  specialized crime suppression group; a K-9 team with a drug dog was assigned to
  the road-block.Â  The dog and his handler walked up and down the line of cars as
  they were stopped at the checkpoint.
Respondent was
  stopped and surrendered his drivers license.Â  As the officer walked back to
  check respondentâ€™s tag, he radioed in and learned respondentâ€™s license was
  suspended.Â  Respondent was asked to pull his car into a nearby parking lot,
  then exit it, and meet the officer at the rear of the vehicle.Â  
The K-9 officer and
  dog left the line and approached respondentâ€™s car.Â  The dog alerted, the car
  was searched, and marijuana seeds were found on the floorboards.Â  Respondent
  was placed in the back of a patrol car before being transported to the law
  enforcement center.Â  After respondent exited the police vehicle at the center,
  the officer found a baggie containing two other bags, each having white powder
  in it.Â  The baggies were found to contain 13.02 grams of cocaine.Â  Respondent
  was â€œMirandizedâ€ at the station, and admitted smoking marijuana but denied the
  cocaine was his. 
Respondent moved to
  suppress the drugs alleging the roadblock was violative of the Fourth
Amendment.Â  The trial judge agreed, and the Stateâ€™s appeal follows.

SCOPE OF REVIEW
A trial courtâ€™s
  Fourth Amendment suppression ruling must be affirmed if supported by any
  evidence, and an appellate court may reverse only when there is clear error.Â  State
    v. Brockman, 339 S.C. 57, 528 S.E.2d 661 (2000).Â  
ISSUES

  
    1)
     Whether the circuit court erred in
    finding the primary purpose of the checkpoint was for general crime control and
    therefore it was violative of the Fourth Amendment under City of
    Indianapolis v. Edmond, 531 U.S. 32 (2000)?
    
  
  
    2)
    Whether the circuit court erred in
    holding that even if the primary purpose was a license checkpoint and there was
    no Edmond flaw, the roadblock none-the-less violated the Fourth
    Amendment under Brown v. Texas, 443 U.S. 47 (1979)?
  

ANALYSIS
The
  controlling decision in this matter is City of Indianapolis v. Edmond,
  531 U.S. 32 (2000).Â  In Edmond, the Court held that a police checkpoint
  whose primary purpose is general crime control- in Edmond narcotics
  interdiction- is unreasonable under the Fourth Amendment.
Here, the circuit
  court judge acknowledged there was conflicting evidence on the true purpose of
  the checkpoint, but was persuaded the primary purpose was general crime
  suppression rather then merely a driversâ€™ license checkpoint.Â  He pointed to
  the following facts to support his conclusion:

  
    1) 
     the checkpoint was conducted by
  the Directed Patrol Unit, which is assigned specifically to deal with crime
  suppression issues;
  
  
  
    2) 
    a K-9 patrol unit with a
  nationally certified drug dog team was participating; and,
  
  
  
    3)
    the State presented no evidence as
  to the plan, procedures, or duration of the roadblock, nor was any evidence of
  a protocol introduced and as the Supreme Court noted in Edmond, without
  such information “law enforcement authorities would be able to establish
  checkpoints for virtually any purpose so long as they include a license or
  sobriety check.”  
  

The
  circuit court went on to find that even if the primary purpose were a license
  checkpoint and thus the roadblock passed constitutional muster under Edmond,
  the roadblock would still violate the Fourth Amendment under Brown v. Texas,
  443 U.S. 47 (1979).Â  Brown established a three part balancing test for
determining the constitutionality of a traffic checkpoint:

  
    1)
    the gravity of the public interest
  served by the seizure;
  
  
  
    2) 
    the degree to which the seizure
  serves the public interest; and,
  
  
  
    3) 
    the severity of the interference
  with individual liberty.
  

The trial judge held the
  first and third factors easily weighed in the Stateâ€™s favor, but found that the
State presented no evidence on the second factor.
The
  State first argues the trial judge erred in finding the primary purpose here
  was suppression of drug activity.Â  It does not argue that there is no evidence
  to support the ruling, but instead contends the judge placed â€œundue emphasisâ€
  on certain facts.Â  Under this Courtâ€™s limited scope of review, the finding that
  the primary purpose of the roadblock was general crime suppression is supported
  by the evidence, and the conclusion that it violated the Fourth Amendment under Edmond must be affirmed.Â  State v. Brockman, supra.
The State next
  argues the trial judge abused his discretion finding the State failed to meet
  the second Brown factor, the â€œeffectivenessâ€ requirement.Â  The State
  argues that it need not introduce evidence about the specific effectiveness of
  this roadblock because, by its very nature, every license check roadblock
  determines whether the driver is legally licensed. Â The Stateâ€™s position that
  license check roadblocks are ipso facto constitutional, thereby
  eliminating the requirement of effectiveness from the Brown formula relies
  upon Michigan Depâ€™t of State Police v. Sitz, 496 U.S. 444 (1990).Â  While Sitz does criticize â€œsearching examination of effectivenessâ€ by trial
  courts, it retains the requirement that the State produce empirical data to
  support the effectiveness of its roadblock. Sitz at 454 (â€œunlike [Delaware
    v. Proust, 440 U.S. 648 (1979), this case [does not involve] a complete
  absence of empirical data . . . .â€). Â The record supports the trial courtâ€™s finding
  that the State failed to produce any evidence satisfying the second prong of
  the Brown test.
CONCLUSION
There is evidence
  in the record supporting the trial judgeâ€™s finding that the primary purpose of
  this roadblock was general crime suppression and therefore his conclusion that
  the roadblock violated Edmond must be affirmed.Â  State v. Brockman, supra.Â  Even if we were to disagree with this finding, the record
  supports the trial judgeâ€™s secondary holding that the Stateâ€™s failure to
  produce any evidence on the second prong of the Brown v. Texas test
  renders the checkpoint unconstitutional.Â  Id.Â  Accordingly, the order
  suppressing the evidence is
AFFIRMED.

MOORE, WALLER
and BEATTY, JJ., concur. TOAL, C.J., dissenting in a separate opinion.

Chief Justice Toal:Â  I respectfully dissent.Â  I would reverse the trial courtâ€™s order
  suppressing the evidence and hold that this checkpoint did not violate the
  Fourth Amendment.
In City of Indianapolis v. Edmond, 531 U.S. 32 (2000), the United States
  Supreme Court held that the Fourth Amendment prohibits law enforcement from
  setting up a traffic checkpoint where the â€œprogrammaticâ€ primary purpose is
  general crime control.Â  The relevant jurisprudence instructs that the test to
  determine the primary purpose of a checkpoint is an objective test, and that
  the examining court should â€œconsider all the
  available evidence in order to determine the relevant primary purpose.â€Â  Ferguson v. City of Charleston, 532
  U.S. 67, 81 (2001) (citing Edmond, 531 U.S. at 45-47).Â  
In my view, there is no evidence in the record to
  support the trial courtâ€™s finding that the primary purpose of this checkpoint
  was general crime control.Â  The record shows that in accordance with the
  sheriffâ€™s departmentâ€™s guidelines, law enforcement officers placed signs on
  each road approaching the checkpoint alerting drivers to the checkpoint.Â  Law
  enforcement officers stopped every vehicle, detained the drivers for no more
  than two minutes, and only after ascertaining probable cause would they ask the
  driver to pull off the road into a parking lot for further questioning.Â 
  Additionally, an officer testified that the purpose of the checkpoint was to
  verify that every driver had a valid license and registration.Â  Considering all
  the evidence in the record, I do not believe that the primary purpose of this
  checkpoint was general crime prevention, nor do I believe that this checkpoint
  allowed officers to exercise standardless and unconstrained discretion.Â  See Delaware v. Prouse, 440 U.S. 648, 663 (1979) (invalidating discretionary
  â€œspot checkingâ€ in which the officer stopped random motorists on public
  highways solely for the purpose of checking the driversâ€™ license and
  registration).Â  
Further, in my opinion, the
  majority errs in suggesting that Brown v. Texas, 443 U.S. 47 (1979)
  requires the State to provide empirical data regarding the effectiveness of
  checkpoints or that Mich. Dept. of State Police v. Sitz, 496
  U.S. 444 (1990) retained this requirement.Â  In
  ruling on the constitutionality of a suspicionless checkpoint in which police
  stopped every vehicle, the Sitz court noted that the case did not
  involve â€œa complete absence of empirical data.â€Â  Id. at 454Â  However,
  the Supreme Court went on to hold that the second prong of the Brown test
  â€œwas not meant to transfer from politically accountable officials
  to the courts the decision as to which among reasonable alternative law
  enforcement techniques should be employed to deal with a serious public dangerâ€
  and that â€œfor purposes of Fourth Amendment analysis . . . [this decision] remains with the
  governmental officials.â€Â  Sitz, 496 U.S. at 454. 
In my view, the balance of the public
  interest and the severity of the interference with individual liberty clearly
  weighs in favor of this checkpoint.Â  As noted by the trial court, the intrusion
  on individual liberty was minimal and the State has a high interest in
  preventing unlicensed or uninsured drivers from operating vehicles.Â  In my
  opinion, this checkpoint provides an effective method of curtailing this
  problem in that every vehicle was stopped and every driver was required to
  produce their license, registration, and proof of insurance.Â  Moreover, the
  fact remains that decisions regarding the techniques and methods of combating
  roadway dangers remains with law enforcement.Â  See Id. Â Perhaps most significant, however, is that this
  checkpoint modeled the types of checkpoints that have been upheld as
  constitutional under the Fourth Amendment.Â  See Sitz, 496 U.S. at 455 (holding that a
  suspicionless seizure where law enforcement briefly stopped all motorists crossing
  the checkpoint did not violate the Fourth Amendment); Prouse, 440
  U.S. at 663 (distinguishing between the unconstitutional seizure of drivers
  without reasonable suspicion and the â€œ[q]uestioning of all
  oncoming traffic at roadblock-type stopsâ€); United States
    v. Martinez-Fuerte, 428 U.S. 543, 566 (1976) (holding
  that â€œstops for brief questioning routinely conducted at
  permanent checkpoints are consistent with the Fourth Amendmentâ€).Â  Indeed,
  while Edmond held that the Fourth Amendment prohibits a suspicionless
  stop whose â€œprogrammaticâ€ primary purpose is general crime control, the
  â€œholding [] [did] nothing to
  alter the constitutional status of the sobriety and border checkpoints that
[the United States Supreme Court] approved in Sitz and Martinez-Fuerte, or of the type of traffic checkpoint that we suggested would be lawful in Prouse.â€Â  Edmond at 47.

For these reasons, I would hold that the
  primary purpose of this checkpoint was not general crime prevention and that
  the checkpoint did not violate Appellantâ€™s Fourth Amendment rights.Â
